genInfo: Headache is a common complaint, only 10% have a treatable cause and only 0.5% are serious. The most common cause is stress, which may be due to work or family difficulties. Other causes include eye strain and dehydration.
history:
Ask about:
• Duration; hours, days, weeks or even months.
• Site - on top of head pressing down or like a tight band around the head.
• Work environment; long hours, shift work, computer use, deadlines, exams.
• Uncomfortable work position and/or bad posture.
• Eyestrain, sleep deprivation.
• Difficulty in concentrating.
• Dehydration or hunger, irregular meal times, caffeine withdrawal.
• Exposure to cold air or eating cold food/drink may cause an “ice creamheadache”.
• Social factors, relationship stress, alcohol intake, irregular meals.
• Nausea/vomiting; consider Migraine.
• Fever, rash, neck stiffness or photophobia, consider Meningitis.
• Recent head injury including boxing. See protocol 1.2
examination:
Check for:
• Temp, pulse, BP, PERLA and visual acuity.
• Neck stiffness, neck examination. Chin to chest.
• Skin rash.
management:
Management Basic and Intermediate Level

Treatment: 
Analgesia, Paracetamol 2 x 500mg tablets qds and/or Ibuprofen 400mg tablets tds.

Advice: Avoid precipitating factors and consider Occupational Health aspects: Consider light duties. B chit 1/7.
occHealth:
Occupational Health:

Ask them to consider duration of work, office lighting, computer use, sources of stress. If eye strain is suspected encourage the patient to book an eye test via an optician. Display screen equipment (DSE) eyesight examination vouchers for use at Specsavers can be obtained via the unit admin office.
refer: Recent head injury or similar symptoms in preceding month. Refer to MO if no improvement after 24 hours.
highlight:
Immediate referral warning signs

Increasing severity of headache.
• Irritability or irrational behaviour.
• Persistent vomiting.
• Photophobia, blurred or double vision.
• Neck stiffness.
• Decreased conscious level.
• Convulsions.

The above may be either due to a mass in the brain such as bleed inside the skull, leading to raised pressure inside the skull or if associated with a fever may be due to an acute brain infection.

genInfo: Any significant injury or blow to the head will cause a mild brain injury, also called concussion. This usually resolves after minutes or days but sometimes headaches may persist for months or rarely years. These long term headaches are called post traumatic or post-concussion headaches and may be associated with changes in mental function such as poor concentration and memory.
history:
Ask about:
• Mechanism of head injury.
• Duration of any loss of consciousness.
• Duration of any pre and post traumatic amnesia.
• Site and nature of pain now.
• Nausea and/or vomiting.
• Visual symptoms e.g. double vision or blurring of vision.
• Previous head injury or brain surgery.
examination:
Check for:
• Temp, pulse, BP, PERLA, and visual acuity.
• Check skull for tenderness, bruising, swelling or cuts.
• Check movement, sensation and power of limbs. Look for any loss of sensation or power and compare one side to the other.
management:
Management Basic Level

Document your history and examination findings and then refer to the MO.

Management Intermediate Level
Treatment:
• Paracetamol 2 x 500mg tablets qds and/or Ibuprofen 400mg tablets tds.
• Consider LD Chit B 3/7 max. To see MO if longer period required.

Advice:
• Print and hand the patient the Patient’s Guide to Concussion leaflet. Read through the symptoms and make sure they know how to contact medical help if their condition deteriorates.
• Advise them to avoid tiring journeys, driving, contact sports, stress and alcohol until the headache has resolved. Good sleep and gentle exercise may help.
occHealth:
Occupational Health:

No contact sports for a minimum of one week. Consider restriction on driving, weapons and use of DSE for short period if any visual or concentration symptoms.
refer: If the head injury was minor without loss of consciousness or loss of memory (amnesia) and all observations are normal then analgesia may be given and routine referral made with the doctor within 24 hrs.
highlight:
Immediate referral warning signs

Increasing severity of headache.
• Irritability or irrational behaviour.
• Persistent vomiting.
• Photophobia, blurred or double vision.
• Neck stiffness.
• Decreased conscious level or convulsions.

These signs may be due to a space occupying lesion such as intracranial bleed, leading to raised intracranial pressure or if associated with a fever may be due to acute meningitis.

genInfo: Moderate or severe, mostly unilateral, headaches associated with nausea and vomiting, light sensitivity (photophobia) andincreased sensitivity to sound (phonophobia).One third of migraines are preceded by an aura which is an unusual visual, olfactory orother sensory experience. Migraines typically last from 4 -72 hours. Trigger factors may include fatigue, anxiety, stress, depression, changes in diet such as fasting, irregular meals, bright lights, noise, hypoxia, strong odours, menstrual cycle hormones and oral contraceptive pill. Certain food items such as cheese, chocolate or alcohol may also trigger migraines.
history:
Ask About: 
• Gradual development of a unilateral headache becoming throbbing or pulsating in nature and made worse by slightest movement or noise. 
• Early symptoms of tiredness, yawning, pallor and visual disturbance such as spots or flashing lights in front of eyes. 
• Photophobia, nausea and vomiting, phonophobia. 
• PMH: migraine. 
• Recent commencement or change of contraceptive pill.
examination:
Check for:
• Temp, pulse, BP, visual acuity, PERLA.
• Tone, power, co-ordination, sensation.
management:
Management Basic Level

Document your history and examination findings and then refer either to a senior medic or medical officer.

Management Intermediate Level

Treatment:
Known migraine sufferers should keep adequate analgesia so that they can self medicate as soon as the symptoms start.
• Paracetamol 2 x 500mg tablets qds or Migraleve tablets. Note: Paracetamol and Migraleve must not be supplied together. Migraleve maximum is two pink and 6 yellow tablets in 24hrs.

• LD Chit B 1/7 if moderate to severe.
• C chit if severe. Admit to MRS if living in single accommodation

Advice: Lying down in a darkened room maybe helpful. If this does not relieve symptoms after a few hours, refer to MO.
occHealth:
Occupational Health:

Identify and avoid trigger factors where possible.Do not drive until symptoms resolve.
Computer work may exacerbate symptoms.
If symptoms regularly impact work – refer to MO for grading consideration.
refer: If symptoms are more severe than previous attacks or otherwise atypical for patient.
highlight:
Immediate referral warning signs

• Loss of tone, power or co-ordination may occur in migraine but should prompt urgent referral to exclude serious causes.
• Refer after 24hrs if no improvement with analgesia.

genInfo: Acute inflammation of the mucosal lining ofthe paranasal sinuses. Usually viral in origin, causing blockage and retention of mucus.This may become secondarily infected by resident bacterial organisms of the nose.
history:
Ask about:
• Headache: facial pain increased by bending forward.
• Nasal congestion, runny nose, sneezing.
• PMH: Previous URTI, cough, sputum, fever, post nasal drip.
• Previous episodes incl. requirement for antibiotics – some patients can suffer recurrent episodes
• Symptoms can last several weeks leading to fatigue
examination:
Check for:
• Temp, pulse, BP.
• Palpation for facial tenderness.
• Ear and throat exam.
• Chest auscultation.
management:
Management Basic Level:

Document your history and examination findings and then refer either to a senior medic or medical officer.

Management Intermediate Level
Treatment:

• Paracetamol 2 x 500mg tablets qds or Ibuprofen 400mg tds with food.
• Steam inhalations, antihistamines or decongestants may be helpful.
• Menthol and Eucalyptus Inhalation BP or menthol crystals.Add one teaspoon to a pint of hot, not boiling, water and inhale the vapour in the treatment room.
• Consider LD Chit C 1-2/7 or B1-2/7 depending on severity; if bedded down review prior to returning to work. Admit to MRS if living in single accommodation.

Advice: Advise to stop smoking.
occHealth:
Occupational Health:

Chronic or recurrent sinusitis may cause employment problems particularly for divers and aircrew.
refer: Severe pain, fever and/or failure to improve after 24 hrs of treatment.
highlight:
Immediate referral warning signs

Facial swelling, particularly if red or hot and tender to touch over the sinus areas may indicate a serious infection and requires urgent referral.

Note: Up to 70% of cases resolve without any treatment but some may require antibiotics or corticosteroid nasal spray. Menthol crystals and menthol solution are caustic so should be used under direction in the treatment room. They must not be issued to the patient.

genInfo: Inflammation of the external ear which may be due to infection. The infection may be generalised, affecting the whole outer ear canal, or localised, as painful boils in the external canal producing purulent, bloody discharge. It may be acute (less than 6 weeks) or chronic (more than 3 months).
history:
Ask about:
• Unilateral or bilateral pain or discomfort/ itching.
• Discharge (otorrhoea) – amount, frequency, colour (e.g., yellow, white)
• Hearing loss or tinnitus.
• Use of cotton buds to clean ears / other potential foreign bodies.
• PMH: Eczema, previous ear infections, other ENT history e.g., previous surgery. diabetes or other immunocompromise
• Diving, swimming, (especially in outdoor settings), use of headsets or ear defenders.
examination:
Check for:
• Temp +/- HR and BP if unwell.
• Otoscope examination of the ears to exclude foreign body.
• Inflammation of the canal with scaly debris and sometimes purulent discharge.
• The tympanic membrane is usually unaffected but can be difficult to visualise.
investigation:
• Swab if copious discharge, as this may help determine antibiotic sensitivity.
• Audiometry if hearing loss suspected.
management:
Management Basic and Intermediate Level

Document your history and examination findings and then refer to the medical officer.
occHealth:
Occupational Health:

Avoid swimming or immersing ears in the bath whilst inflamed. LD Chit; no swimming for 3 days or until seen MO.
• Follow up audiometry one month later if hearing loss with episode.
• Specific advice regarding use of ear defenders and signallers headsets when there has been infection or irritation of the external canal.
refer: Document your history and examination findings and then refer to the medical officer.
highlight: Frequently caused by bacterial pathogens such as Pseudomonas and Staphylococcus aureus but may also be caused by fungal overgrowth especially after antibiotic treatment.

genInfo: Inflammation of the middle ear usually due to bacterial or viral infection. Ear infections often arise as a complication of a cold or sore throat, are common and can be associated with considerable pain. Most are viral and the only treatment required is adequate analgesia. Chronic Otitis Media with Effusion (OME) or “Glue ear” is a common childhood condition which may affect hearing or result in perforation of the tympanic membrane.
history:
Ask about:
• Unilateral or bilateral ear pain.
• Sore throat, cough, runny or stuffy nose.
• Fever or vomiting.
• Dizziness, hearing loss.
• Discharge from the ears.
• PMH: Ear problems or grommets as a child.
• Use of cotton buds to clean ears.
examination:
Check for:
• Temp, Pulse.
• Auroscope examination of the ears to exclude foreign body. Note grommets  (tiny plastic tube surgically inserted into eardrum) in situ, scarring from previous perforation or foreign body. The tympanic membrane may be obscured by impacted wax in the canal or pus/other debris.
• Inflamed (red, shiny) and bulging tympanic membrane, injection (enlargement) of vessels, loss of light reflex.
• Perforation (rupture of eardrum leaving to a hole in drum) may occur with purulent discharge from the middle ear.
management:
Management Basic Level

Document your history and examination findings and then refer either to a senior medic or medical officer.Management Intermediate LevelTreatment:
• Paracetamol 2 x 500mg tablets qds or Ibuprofen 400mg tablet tds with food.

Consider LD Chit B1-2/7 or C 1-2/7 if severe.Admit to the MRS if living in single accommodation and if bedded down, review prior to returning to work.

Advice: Otitis media resolves in 80% of cases without antibiotics. NB: Antibiotics do not reduce the pain in the first 24 hrs, subsequent attacks or deafness, but some studies show a reduction in overall pain.
occHealth:
Occupational Health:

• Avoid swimming whilst inflamed.
• Patient with otitis media should not fly until symptoms resolved and normal valsalva manoeuvre demonstrated.
• Arrange follow up audiometry if there is any hearing loss with the episode.
refer:
• Significant infection or perforation.
• Refer those with significant discomfort, fever or diabetes.
• Sudden hearing loss.

genInfo: Hearing loss may be “conductive” due to a blockage in the ear canal along its length or “sensorineural” due to nerve damage. Conductive deafness may be from an accumulation of earwax, blockage of the Eustachian tube during a cold or a foreign body in the ear canal. Excess noise is a common cause of work related sensorineural hearing loss. Audiometry should be performed within 6 months of commencing and returning from an operational tour and annually for all individuals graded H3 or significantly noise exposed in the workplace.
history:
Ask about:
• Hearing loss unilateral/bilateral.
• Sudden/gradual onset.
• Duration.
• Ear pain.
• Last operational tour date.
• Occupational and social noise exposure.
• Trauma.
• Recent cold/flu.
• Infection.
• Discharge.
• Tinnitus.
• Balance disturbance/dizziness.
• Medication.
• Exposure to Explosion/IED.
examination:
Check for:
• Auroscope examination. Look for impacted wax, signs of infection or perforation.
• Valsalva manoeuvre; pinch the nose and either swallow or try to blow out with the mouth closed. Note if the eardrum does not move.
management:
Management Basic Level

Document your history and examinationfindings and then refer to medical officer.

Management Intermediate Level

Treatment: See Earwax protocol 3.4 if blocked by earwax.

Advice: Stress the importance of earprotection.
occHealth:
Occupational Health:
• Check to see if the patient is appropriately graded.
• Recheck audio in two weeks to confirm hearing loss.
• May need WPA and involvement of SHEF.
• Increased frequency of audiograms if occupational noise exposure or current/previous history of hearing loss.
• Remove from source of noise especially ranges.
• Use of ear defenders according to HSW guidelines.
refer:
Refer:
• Loud noise exposure.
• First presentation of H3 grade.
• Unilateral hearing loss.
highlight:
Note:

The 8kHz result must be recorded on DMICP, even though this does not contribute to the PULHHEEMS grade. Note the review date in the bottom box of the template to set the diary entry. Current policy is to downgrade early to prevent further damage but this can have significant career implications.

genInfo: Earwax is produced by healthy ears and protects the skin as well as providing somebactericidal activity. Impacted earwax (cerumen) in the external auditory canal is only a problem if it causes pain or hearing loss.
history:
Ask about:
• Hearing loss, often sudden after bath or swimming.
• Pain or irritation.
• Use of cotton buds.
examination:
Otoscope examination. Wax may appear yellow/white or black/brown if old/impacted. 
Tympanic membrane (ear drum) may still be visible, or canal may be completely blocked (appear dark).
management:
Management Basic Level

Document your history and examination findings and then refer either to a senior medic or medical officer.

Management Intermediate Level

Treatment: 
Soften the wax with warmed Olive Oil BP drops and remove by gradually washing out in the shower. Sodium Bicarbonate 5% ear drops are available but may be more irritant than olive oil so are not recommended.

Advice: Cotton buds should never be used as they stimulate wax production and usually push the wax further into the canal, causing impaction or pain and risking perforation of the eardrum.
occHealth:
Occupational Health:

Arrange follow up audiometry if there is any hearing loss with the episode.
refer:
• Sudden hearing loss, pain or discomfort.
• Persistent impacted wax despite treatment.
highlight:
Immediate referral warning signs

Do not proceed if there is pain, evidence ofinfection, dizziness, nausea or possibility ofperforation.Note:
• Ear syringing can cause or exacerbate an outer ear infection and is no longer recommended.
• Consider a foreign body in the ear canal if there is persistent or offensive discharge.

genInfo: In a military setting this is most often as a result of blast injury, particularly from IEDs.The structures of the ear are designed to collect and magnify sounds, so that thetympanic membrane moves with the sounds. Unfortunately, the ear’s structures also collect and magnify pressure waves. At a pressure of about 35 kilopascals (5 PSI), the human eardrum may rupture. With an overpressure of 100 kPa (14 PSI) almost all eardrums rupture. At lesser pressures, the overpressure may cause haemorrhage into the drum without a rupture. With extremely high pressures, the drum may be destroyed and the ossicles dislocated or fractured.
history:
Ask about:
• Pain.
• Hearing loss,
• Tinnitus (continuous buzzing or ringing in the ears).
• Dizziness or loss of balance.
examination: Examination with an auroscope may reveal blood in the external canal and show evidence of the perforation of the tympanic membrane(s).
management:
Management Basic and Intermediate Level

Document your history and examination findings and then refer either to a senior medic or medical officer.
occHealth:
Occupational Health:
• Arrange follow up audiometry.
• No swimming. LD Chit; No swimming for 2 weeks.
• Limit further noise exposure. LD Chit: No ranges.
refer: Document your history and examination findings and then refer either to a senior medic or medical officer.
highlight:
Note:

In an acute setting, if the patient shows signs of significant ear damage then there may also be corresponding injury to the lungs and gastrointestinal tract.

genInfo: Any injury in or around the orbital region is classed as an eye injury. The history must detail the mechanism of injury as this will determine the appropriate course of action. Blunt injury can result in a wide variety of injuries from an orbital blowout fracture of the skull to dislocation of the lens, retinal tears and damage to the iris and anterior chamber of the eye. Penetrating injuries on the other hand can be subtle and difficult to detect but are just as damaging as blunt injury.
history:
Ask about:

• Mechanism of injury.
• Pain.
• Haemorrhage and discharge.
• Loss or impairment of vision.
• Double vision.
• Head injury including loss of consciousness and nosebleed.

Penetrating injuries beware:

• Hammer and chisel fragments.
• Glass, knives, thorns, darts, pencils.
• Masonry, bullet and missile fragments.
examination:
Visually inspect both eyes and check:

• Starting with the tissues around the orbits note any damage/pain, bone tenderness,in particular inferior orbit and loss of skinsensation below the eye.
• Look for any bulging of the eyes (proptosis) which could indicate bleeding behind the eye
• Check the sclera, then the cornea and that the pupils are even and round.
• Note the reaction of both pupils to light and accommodation.
• Examine the range of eye movements, comparing the two sides.
• Always check and record the visual acuity.
• Evert the upper lids if trained to do so.
• Subconjunctival haemorrhage, which is a burst blood vessel on the eye surface, will appear as a dramatic red bruise. This normally resolves without treatment in 1-2 weeks.
management:
Management Basic Level 

Document your history and examination findings and then refer either to a senior medic or medical officer. 

Management Intermediate Level 

Minor Injury:
• Superficial damage to the surrounding tissue with no loss of vision or corneal discomfort: Reassure.
• Clean wounds as necessary. Cover with eye shield bandage and patch.
• Paracetamol 2 x 500mg tablets qds.
• Refer To MO. 

Moderate or severe injury: Refer immediately.
occHealth:
Occupational Health:

Adequate eye protection, issue sunglasses or goggles, provide UV and foreign body protection.
refer: If there was significant trauma or corneal abrasion is suspected.
highlight:
Immediate referral warning signs:


Any high velocity injury must be referred. This cannot be overstressed as a suspected or obvious penetrating injury resulting in even a tiny amount of foreign material in the vitreous humor can lead to scarring and subsequent blindness.

genInfo: Corneal abrasions are common. The scratch may result from foreign bodies, fingernails, vegetation or even prolonged rubbing of an irritated eye. Most heal within 1-2 days.
history:
Ask about: History of foreign body or something touching the eye surface.

Red Flags: Exclude significant changes in vision, significant trauma or marked eye pain, headache or photophobia
examination:
Visually inspect both eyes and check for:
• Difficulty opening due to pain.
• Watery or purulent discharge.
• Inflammation of the conjunctiva.
• Note the reaction of both pupils to light and accommodation.
• Evert the eyelid, if trained to do so as the FB may be caught under the lid.
• Always check and record the visual acuity.
management:
Management Basic Level 

Document your history and examination findings and then refer to a MO. The eye may be irrigated whilst waiting to see the MO. 

Management Intermediate Level 

Treatment:
• Irrigate the eye with eyewash, Normal Saline from an IV giving set or clean water to wash away debris.
• Review after 24hrs to ensure resolution of symptoms. There is no evidence to show that eye patches improve pain relief.
occHealth:
Occupational Health:

• Adequate eye protection for the task.
• Issue sunglasses or goggles to provide UV and foreign body protection
• Consider LD B chit for weapon handling.
refer: All cases to MO for antibiotic ointment.
highlight:
Note:
Use of contact lenses in dusty environments or for prolonged periods may cause corneal abrasions.

Red Flags: Exclude significant changes in vision, significant trauma or marked eye pain, headache or photophobia

genInfo: Damage to eye caused by a foreign object. If the mechanism of injury involves a foreign body travelling at high speed or a metal fragment then it is important to consider the possibility of a penetrating eye injury. Foreign bodies (FB) are common in mechanics working under a vehicle or activities such as using a chisel without eye protection. Dust or sand are common foreign bodies in windy weather on ranges or operations.
history:
Ask about:
• Mechanism of injury or onset of symptoms.
• Level of pain.
examination:
Visually inspect both eyes and check for:
• Difficulty opening due to pain.
• Watery or purulent discharge.
• Inflammation of the conjunctiva.
• Note reaction of both pupils to light and accommodation.
• Evert the eyelid, if trained to do so as the FB may be caught under the lid.
• Always check and record the visual acuity.
management:
Management Basic and Intermediate Level

Treatment: 
Irrigate the eye with eyewash, Normal Saline from an IV giving set or clean water to wash away debris or remaining foreign bodies.

Do not remove FB that are visible and protruding out of the globe.
occHealth:
Occupational Health:

Adequate eye protection for the task; ensure that the sunglasses or goggles provide UV and foreign body protection.
refer: Document your history and examination findings and then refer all cases to the MO.

genInfo: A wide range of chemicals can damage the eye. Battery acid splashes to face are a common cause in vehicle mechanics.Alkali burns are particularly damaging and may cause a penetrating eye injury. Loose bits of lime should be removed from the corner of the eyes. Check TOXBASE to assess specific chemical toxicity to the eye.
history:
Ask about:
• Type of chemical.
• Level of pain.
examination:
If chemicals have been splashed into the eye wash out first then examine. 

Visually inspect both eyes and check:
• The sclera, then cornea and pupils.
• Note both pupils reaction to light and accommodation.
• Examine the range of eye movements.
• Always check and record the visual acuity.
• Evert the upper lids; if trained to do so.
management:
Management Basic Level 

Document your history and examination findings and then refer to a MO. 

Management Intermediate Level 

Treatment:
• Irrigate the eye with eyewash, Normal Saline from an IV giving set or clean water to wash away chemicals or debris. Keep irrigating for 15 minutes whilst arranging urgent referral.
• Test the PH level of fluid in eye before and after irrigation to confirm chemical properly flushed out.
• Consider B chit for 1/7.
occHealth:
Occupational Health:

Adequate eye protection for the task.
refer: All cases urgently
highlight:
Immediate referral warning signs:

Do not delay referral to definitive care whilst examining or recording your findings. Chemical injuries need urgent expert review.

genInfo: Red painful eye caused by UV light damage from reflected sunlight off snow or water, laser or welding damage to eye.The pain may not be apparent until some hours after exposure to the damaging UV rays. Prevention is important. Treatment is the same as for corneal abrasion.
history:
Ask about:
• Pain.
• Weeping, discharge.
• Loss or impairment of vision.
examination:
Visually inspect both eyes and check:
• The sclera, then cornea and pupils.
• Note both pupils reaction to light and accommodation.
• Examine the range of eye movements.
• Record visual acuity.
management:
Management Basic Level 

Document your history and examination findings and then refer either to a senior medic or medical officer. 

Management Intermediate Level 

Treatment: Paracetamol 2 x 500mg tablets qds. Advice:
• Isolation in a dark room and cold compresses may help.
• Remove contact lenses and do not wear again until fully resolved.
occHealth:
Occupational Health:

Stress use of good eye protection; sunglasses with side shield or protective goggles, particularly at altitude. If vision affected consider LD chit for weapon handling.
refer:
• All cases, particularly if no improvement after 24 hrs.
• If any sign of corneal abrasion.

genInfo:
Inflammation of the conjunctiva: Bacterial conjunctivitis usually presents with a sore, itchy, red eye with purulent discharge. In most cases bacterial conjunctivitis initially affects only one eye. Rapid spread of infection to the unaffected eye is often the result of direct physical transmission of the infective agent. Bacterial conjunctivitis requires treatment with antibiotics.
Viral conjunctivitis usually presents with a non-purulent watery discharge commonly seen in connection with other concurrent viral upper respiratory tract infections such as a sore throat or common cold. This condition usually settles spontaneously in 1-2 weeks.
history:
Ask about:
• Contact lens use.
• Discomfort, gritty or itchy sensation.
• Watery or purulent discharge.
• Bilateral/unilateral.
examination:
Visually inspect both eyes and check for:
• Corneal abrasion or foreign body.
• Painful cluster of vesicles around the eye (may be shingles).
• Red injected sclera.
• Always check and record the visual acuity.
investigation: Swab only if persistent or recurrent. Consider Chlamydia swab if not responding to antibiotics.
management:
Management Basic Level 

Document your history and examination findings and then refer either to a senior medic or medical officer. 

Management Intermediate Level 

Treatment:
• Clean the eye with eye wash or sterile water.
• Chloramphenicol 1% eye ointment qds. (Except contact lens wearers – must see MO)

Advice: Remove contact lenses, clean thoroughly and do not wear again until infection cleared. Care should be taken by examiner and the patient to avoid cross contamination from affected to non-affected eye.
occHealth:
Public Health:

Conjunctivitis is a contagious condition. Avoid sharing towels/face clothes. Light duties may be required to excuse weapon handling if vision is affected and swimming should be avoided until the infection has cleared. 

Severe cases should be seen by the MO and may require bedding down.
refer:
• Contact lens wearers.
• Infection not clearing after 48hrs antibiotic use.
• Periorbital swelling (cellulitis).
• Known Herpes Infection.
• Eye Pain. Reduced Visual Acuity.
highlight:
Note:

Trachoma is a serious form of conjunctivitis, caused by the sexually transmitted disease Chlamydia. Suspect in young adults with bilateral conjunctivitis with mucopurulent discharge and venereal disease. This is a world wide major cause of blindness.

genInfo: Allergic conjunctivitis may be associated with systemic allergies such as hay fever or due to chemical irritation from cosmetics, fumes or eye drops. This condition usually presents with a non-purulent watery discharge, sore and itchy eyes, usually both, often with a gritty sensation on blinking.
history:
Ask about:
• Itching
• FH: of atopy.
• Recent use of chemicals or eye drops.
• Recurrent problem, same time each year.
examination:
Visually inspect both eyes and check for:
• Diffuse redness and oedema of conjunctiva.
• “Cobblestone” swelling of the inside of the upper eyelid.
• Clear, watery discharge.
• Always check and record the visual acuity.
management:
Management Basic Level 

Document your history and examination findings and then refer to the MO. 

Management Intermediate Level 

Treatment: Sodium cromoglicate 2% eye drops. Instil one drop into the affected eye(s) four times a day. 

Advice: Avoid allergens, clean make up off thoroughly.
occHealth:
Occupational Health:

Avoid wearing contact lenses on exercise or deployment, particularly in dry, dusty environments.
refer:
• Painful red eye with visual disturbance.
• No improvement in 48hrs.
• Contact lens wearers.

genInfo:
A meibomian cyst (also known as a chalazion) is a sterile inflammation of the eyelid caused by a reaction to sebum within a meibomian gland.
They may develop gradually and persist for many months. If infection is suspected, then a stye is more likely.
history:
Ask about:
• Duration of symptoms.
• Localised discomfort or pain.
• Increased tearing.
• Sensitivity to light.
examination:
Visually inspect both eyes and check for:
• Chalazion; a larger lump on underside of eyelid.
• Always check and record the visual acuity.
management:
Management Basic and Intermediate Level 

Treatment: 
Chalazion usually settle with conservative treatment but may take many months. 

Antibiotics may be useful in the early stages, later some may require minor surgery. 

Hot compresses of a towel or cotton wool soaked with warm water may relieve the symptoms.
occHealth:
Occupational Health:

Avoid wearing contact lenses on exercise or deployment, particularly in dry, dusty environments.
refer: Infected and/or large chalazia disturbing vision or failure to resolve after 4 weeks.
highlight:
Note:

Avoid wearing contact lenses with any of these conditions.

genInfo: Lumps around the eye lids from retained secretions or infection; a Stye or hordeolum, is an infection of the sebaceous glands at the base of the eyelashes. A small lump which appears suddenly and resolves within a week.
history:
Ask about:
• Duration of symptoms.
• Localised discomfort or pain.
• Increased tearing.
• Sensitivity to light.
examination:
Visually inspect both eyes and check for:
• Stye; red, tender swelling at margin of lid, may discharge pus.
• Always check and record the visual acuity.
management:
Management Basic Level 

Treatment: 
Stye; hot compresses to help “point” the abscess (as above).
occHealth:
Public Health:

Styes are contagious so advise good hygiene especially hand washing.
refer:
Refer:
• Stye that does not respond to treatment.
• If there is an associated fever or signs of localized infection, particularly orbital cellulitis, refer immediately.
highlight:
Note:

Avoid wearing contact lenses with any of these conditions.

genInfo: Chronic inflammation of the margins of the eyelid. Inflammation of the eyelids, with redness, irritation and scaly skin at the margins. Blepharitis is a common disorder that is often associated with eczema and scalp dandruff. Chalazia or styes may develop where the glands are blocked by thes caly skin or crusts.
history:
Ask about:
• Inflamed lid margins.
• Pain or gritty sensation.
• Pain on eye movements.
• PMH Conjunctivitis.
examination:
Visually inspect both eyes and check for:
• Flakes or crusts on eyelashes.
• Chalazia or styes.
• Always check and record the visual acuity.
management:
Management Basic & Intermediate Level 

Treatment: 
The crust on the lids should be gently removed with cotton wool buds dipped in warm water and a few drops of baby shampoo twice daily. 

Advice: Careful daily face washing.
Warm compresses 1-2 times daily for 5-10 mins on closed eyes.
Needs to continue when symptoms resolve to reduce recurrence
occHealth:
Occupational Health:

• Recurrent condition exacerbated by stress, dust or tobacco smoke.
• If frequent recurrences advise re stress management.
refer: Recurrent symptoms or not settling with good hygiene.
highlight:
Immediate referral warning signs:
 
If there is an associated fever or signs of a localised infection or orbital cellulitis refer urgently to a MO.

genInfo: Patient presents with pain or swelling relating to the teeth or related structures with a history of facial trauma.
history:
Ask about:
• Method of injury?
• Were they knocked unconscious or are they feeling sick?
• Do they have double-vision?
• Was there trauma to any other areas of the head?
• Can they bite their teeth together normally?
• Any lower lip, chin or face numbness?
• Limited mouth opening?
• Severe pain?
examination:
Equipment: Gloved Hand, Pocket Torch and Tongue Depressor 

Check for:
• Unwell patient; lethargy, decreased conscious level, nausea. Consider possibility of head injury.
• Normal breathing. Consider airway obstruction by tongue, denture, secondary to maxillary fracture, etc.
• Facial asymmetry.
• Any broken, missing, loose or displaced teeth.
• Lacerations, bruising or swelling inside the mouth.
• Can the patient open their mouth normally?
• Does the bite look grossly normal?
• Palpate all of the oral cavity, especially under the tongue.
• Eye signs- Diplopia, proptosis or restricted eye movement.
management:
Management Basic Level 

• If there is a history of loss of consciousness or nausea? Treat as head injury and contact the MO immediately.  
• If the patient has any facial swelling, an abnormal bite or lacerations or swelling inside the mouth contact the DO immediately.  
• If patient has any broken, loose, displaced or missing teeth call the DO immediately. Any teeth that have been knocked out must be stored in milk or saline solution, not water. 
• If the patient has none of the above refer to senior Medic or Practice Nurse. 

Management Intermediate Level 

Treatment: As above plus appropriate analgesia: Paracetamol 500mg 2 tablets qds or ibuprofen 400mg tds with food. 

Advice:
• Arrange for them to see the DO at the next possible sick parade.
• Advise warm salt water mouth rinses for minor intra oral soft tissue trauma
refer: If in any doubt call the DO.

genInfo: The patient presents with a history of pain and/or swelling relating to the teeth or related structures not related to facial trauma.
history:
Ask About:
• Traumatic cause.
• Severity, nature and duration of the pain. Constant or Intermittent, localised to one tooth or diffuse.
• Recent dental treatment.
• Radiation to ear or eyes.
• Pain worse with hot or cold.
• Pain made worse by eating.
• Can patient swallow normally?
examination:
Equipment: Gloved Hand, Pocket Torch and Tongue Depressor. 

Check for:
• Facial swelling or redness.
• Palpate any tender or swollen lymph nodes.
• Look inside mouth for decayed or broken teeth.
• Look at and palpate all soft tissue inside the mouth for any swelling or discharge.
• Palpate teeth gently with finger and note teeth that are tender to palpation.
management:
Management Basic Level 
• If any signs of swelling, redness, lymph node involvement, raised temperature or difficulty swallowing call the DO/MO immediately.  
• If the patient complains of severe pain relating to the teeth or related structures call the DO/MO immediately.  
• If patient is suffering from mild to moderate pain with no signs of spreading infection refer to Senior Medic or Practice Nurse. 

Management Intermediate Level 

Treatment: As above plus appropriate analgesia: Paracetamol 500mg, 2 tablets qds or ibuprofen 400mg tds with food. 

Advice: Arrange for patient to see the DO at next possible sick parade.
refer: If in any doubt call the DO.

genInfo: Toothache is a common patient complaint and is attributable to a number of causes. It is important to consider trauma and that there may be associated injuries. Dental infections must be diagnosed early as these can spread and may be life-threatening. Toothache is managed by simple analgesia and the patient should attend the next dental sick parade.
history:
Ask about:
• If related to trauma, go to 4.1 Traumatic Dental Emergencies.
• If there are signs of swelling, redness or the patient is systemically un-well go to protocol 4.2 Infective Dental Emergencies.
• Now complete the Medics Toothache Proforma

1. How long has the patient had toothache?
2. How bad is the pain on a scale of 0-10? 
(0= no pain; 10= worst pain possible). Is the pain Constant or intermittent?
3. Is the pain affecting the patients sleep?
4. Is the pain made worse by Hot, Cold, sweet or all three? If so, for how long?
5. Is the pain made worse by Chewing or Biting?
6. Which tooth (or teeth) is the pain coming from? 
7. Is the pain relieved by painkillers?
8. Has the patient had a similar problem before? 
9. Has the patient had recent dental treatment in the affected area?
examination:
Equipment: Gloved Hand, Pocket Torch And Tongue Depressor. 

Check for:
• Look for obviously decayed teeth.
• Palpate teeth to see if they are loose.
• Note pain on palpation.
• Note any puss discharging into the mouth.
• Investigation
• Temperature.
management:
Management Basic and Intermediate Level 

Treatment: Appropriate analgesia:
Paracetamol 500mg 2 tablets qds or ibuprofen 400mg tds with food. 

Advice: If pain is assessed as mild to moderate then 
arrange for patient to see the DO at next possible sick 
parade.

Consider LD up to max three days.
refer:
Refer: If the patient complains of severe pain relating to the teeth or related structures or if the pain cannot be controlled by simple analgesia, then ensure the Medics Toothache Proforma has been completed and call the 
DO immediately.

Consider LD up to max three days.

genInfo: Bleeding from the nose. Most nose bleeds are trivial but can be distressing for the patient and need to be dealt with efficiently and quickly.
history:
History Ask about:
• When the bleed started, from which nostril and how much blood has been lost.
• Nose trauma including nose picking.
• Recent cold symptoms or hay fever.
• PMH: Previous episodes.
• Recent medication especially aspirin, NSAID and alcohol.
examination:
Check for:
• Pulse and BP.
• Local inspection of nose looking for bleeding point  (small red dot).
management:
Management Basic and Intermediate Level 

Treatment:
• Pinch nostrils (soft part of nose) and breathe through mouth.
• Lean slightly forward. Hold this for at least 10 minutes (distract themselves with a phone or book while holding).
• Spit blood/saliva out into a bowl. 

• Reassure.
• Ice pack/cold compress or sucking ice cubes may help.
• Observe for 30 mins after the bleed stops.

If simple measures do not control bleeding in 10-15 mins, soak gauze with 5ml Tranexamic Acid (TXA) solution- 1 vial and insert into the nose.

Advice:
• Put yellow soft paraffin around the nostril once bleeding has stopped. This will keep crusting soft and help stop disturbance.
• Avoid blowing (24hrs) or picking the nose, heavy lifting, strenuous exercise, lying flat alcohol and hot drinks. 

Consider LD chit.
occHealth:
Occupational Health:

Nose bleeds are more common in dry, dusty environments.
refer:
• Failure to control bleeding within 10-15 mins with correct technique. [referral for nasal cautery or packing may be needed]

• Already significant blood loss.
• Bleeding suspected to be from the posterior nose (profuse bleeding, from both nostrils, and unable to see a bleeding point on examination).
highlight:
Immediate referral warning signs

If the blood loss is severe, sit the patient down and treat for hypovolaemia as appropriate. Refer to MO.

genInfo: Acute inflammation of the throat and / or tonsils. Sore throats are usually due to viral infection. Bacterial infection is less common and treatment with antibiotics has been shown to reduce the duration of fever by only 8 hrs and is therefore not recommended.
history:
Ask About:
• Duration of sore throat.
• Pain on swallowing.
• Fever.
• Headache, earache or cough.
• Difficulty swallowing saliva or fluids, or drooling.
• If struggling to drink oral fluids, ask when last passed urine.

• Recent usage of any prescription drugs which can cause symptoms of sore throat.
examination:
Check for:
• Temp, pulse, BP.
• Check cervical lymph nodes.
• Examine throat and tonsils for inflammation, white spots or pus.
• Check for bright red tongue with raised white spots.
• Check for any new rash on body
investigation:
Throat swabs are generally not helpful. The MO may consider blood tests for Glandular Fever if symptoms persist.

Use Fever/Pain Score or Centor Criteria (MedCalc or Google) to assess need for antibiotics.
management:
Management Basic & Intermediate Level

Treatment:
• If Fever/Pain Score or Centor Criteria >/= 3 d/w MO about need for antibiotics
• Aspirin 300mg dispersible tablets, gargle 4 x daily OR Paracetamol 2 x 500mg tablets qds AND Ibuprofen 400mg 1 tablet tds with food.
• Benzydamine 0.15% throat spray (Difflam), 4-8 sprays every 1.5-3 hours.

• Chlorhexidine 0.2% Mouthwash. Rinse mouth with 10ml of mouthwash for about one minute, twice a day. Do not swallow.
• LD Chit 2-3/7. If severe or generally unwell, discuss with MO to consider bedding down in accommodation.

Advice: Increase oral fluid intake. Most sore throats will improve after 3-4 days and do not require antibiotic therapy.
refer:
• Urgently if large unilateral swelling - possible quinsy.
• Signs or symptoms of Sepsis.
• Centor Criteria or Fever/Pain Score elevated d/w MO for consideration of antibiotics.
• If unable to swallow fluids or not passed urine in last 6-12hrs may need admission to hospital for fluids. Discuss with MO.

• Routine if not improved in 24hrs with analgesia and rest or recurrent severe sore throat.
highlight:
Note:

Tonsillectomy is an operation that is still sometimes performed but has unproven benefit in adults.

genInfo:
Viral infection of the upper airways, may affect the nose, throat. Common colds or coryza, are spread by droplet infection or hand to hand contact, so hand washing is important. Most are self-limiting, trivial illnesses, which complete their course without serious consequences, usually within a week although the cough may last a bit longer.
Influenza “the flu”, may present with more significant muscle aches and fever/shaking than just cold symptoms, and will usually be a self-limiting condition in a healthy patient, however, will likely require symptom management and rest.
history:
Ask about:
• Dry or sore throat.
• Nasal congestion and watery nasal discharge.
• Sneezing, cough.
• Malaise, muscle or joint pain.
• Fever.
• History of foreign travel.
• Symptoms suggestive of another source of infection (urine, abdominal, brain etc.)
• Unwell contacts.
examination:
Check for:
• Temp, Pulse, RR, PEFR.
• Conjunctivitis.
• Rash on the body – if present check with “glass test” – if does not disappear ensure urgent MO review
• Listen to the chest - Crackles in the chest, if present consider a lower respiratory tract infection
• Wheeze, if present consider asthma

• Red throat or Inflamed neck glands; see 5.2 Sore Throat/Tonsillitis protocol.
management:
Management Basic and Intermediate Level 

Treatment:
• Paracetamol 2 x 500mg tablets qds and/or Aspirin 2 x 300mg dispersible tablets, gargle 4-6hrly  OR Ibuprofen 400mg TDS (with food).
• Consider LD Chit depending on severity; B 1-2/7 or C 1-2/7.
• Consider admission to MRS if living in single accommodation or struggling to self-care.
• If bedded down review prior to returning to work.
• Consider the number of similar cases, discuss with MO if concerns regarding an outbreak.
 

Advice: Steam inhalation or decongestants. Increase oral fluid intake and discourage smoking.
occHealth:
Occupational Health:

Remove soldier from a close work environment if possible in order to reduce the risk of the infection spreading. Encourage the prevention of further spread through individual hygiene measures.
refer:
• Patients with severe symptoms or temperature > 38oC.
• Tachycardia, HR >100.
• If condition worsens or does not improve within 24 hrs.
• Patients who have recently been in countries where malaria is prevalent.
highlight:
Note:

Consider malaria in anyone who has recently been in countries where malaria is prevalent and has a fever
.

genInfo: An infection of the lower respiratory tract. The majority of chest infections are viral and systematic reviews indicate that antibiotics are of no proven benefit in otherwise healthy young adults.
history:
Ask about:
• Productive cough. Sticky, white, green/yellow or blood stained sputum.
• Fever, difficulty breathing, wheezing.
• Chest pain – central? On breathing in? On breathing out?
• Onset and duration of symptoms
• How much impact do symptoms have on 
ability to function/do job?
• PMH: Chest problems/ asthma/ diabetes/ splenectomy.
• Smoking history.
• Allergies
examination:
Check for:
• Temperature, pulse and BP.
• Respiratory rate, PEFR.
• Auscultation of the chest – any wheeze?
• O2 Sat if pulse oximeter available; refer if <96%.
• Chest pain on deep inspiration.
• Are they confused?
investigation:
Sputum sample may be taken for culture and sensitivity, discuss with MO.

Bloods or CXR may be needed if symptoms persist or patient isn’t improving with treatment but aren’t routinely needed, discuss with MO.

Consider Covid-19 testing if SOB, cough, high temperature +/- loss of sense of smell or taste. 
If positive, manage as per most recent guidance.
management:
Management Basic and Intermediate Level 
Treatment:
• Paracetamol 2 x 500mg tablets qds.
• Consider LD Chit 1-3 days light duties/ bedded down depending on severity. Consider admission to the MRS if living in single accommodation.

• If bedded down review prior to returning to work.
• May need antibiotics if bacterial in origin – yellow/green sputum, crackles heard on chest. Refer to MO.
• Safety netting and return for review if no improvement with treatment and rest in 3 days

Advice: Increase oral fluids and discourage smoking. Avoid other paracetamol containing products such as Lemsip, Nightnurse and other branded cough, cold and flu products alongside Paracetamol tablets.
occHealth:
Public Health:

Smoking cessation advice if appropriate. 

Occupational Health:
• Remove from a close work environment if possible to reduce the risk of the infection spreading.
refer:
Refer:
• Wheeziness or a “tight chest” (see Asthma protocols).
• Persistent or significant symptoms for greater than 48hrs.
• Cough with blood in the sputum.
• Pleuritic pain; sharp pain in the chest on taking a deep breath.
• Difficulty breathing
• Confusion or lethargy
• Respirations > 15/min.
• Fever above 38°C and general malaise.
• O2 saturations < 96%.
highlight:
Immediate referral warning signs:

Refer to MO immediately if neck stiffness, photophobia or significantly unwell.

genInfo: Reversible small airway obstruction characterised by wheeze and breathlessness due to constriction of the airways and increased mucus production. Individuals may present during peak hay fever periods or following strenuous exercise, particularly in cold weather.
history:
Ask about:
• Wheeze, tight chest, breathlessness, cough, especially night time.
• DH: Current or previous medication, regular and during this episode.
• PMH: Known asthmatic. Previous hospital admissions for asthma.
• FH: Atopy such as asthma, eczema, hay fever, allergies.
• SH: Smoker (self or in household / workplace).
examination:
Check for:
• RR. > 25bpm = Acute Severe Asthma.
• Chest auscultation: wheeze or reduced breath sounds.
• Temp.
• Pulse. If the PR > 110bpm urgent referral to MO required.
investigation: PEFR; check this against the appropriate normogram to work out percentage of predicted or best.
management:
Management Basic Level 

Document your history and examination findings and then refer to a medical officer 

Management Intermediate Level 

Treatment: one puff of Salbutamol 100mcg cfc-free aerosol inhaler, to be used every 15 to 30 seconds for acute episodes or exacerbations of asthma. 10-20 puffs delivered via spacer device (use a coke bottle or a paper cup if a spacer is not available). 

Advice: Discourage smoking.
occHealth:
Occupational Health:
• If a known asthmatic, check that the soldier has been downgraded.
• The hot, dusty environment of some current operations may exacerbate asthma, even in those who have not had symptoms since childhood.
• Check Medical Risk Assessment predeployment.
refer:
• Cough with up to 15% reduction in PEFR; make a routine appointment the same day.
• Wheeze with increased RR; urgent referral to MO.
highlight:
Immediate referral warning signs

• Moderate asthma attack: PEFR is 50-75% best or predicted.
• Severe asthma attack: PEFR is 33-50% best or predicted.
• Follow Emergency Protocol 16.4 Asthma (in PDF version), contact the MO and evacuate immediately.
drug1: Salbutamol CFC free  Inhaler - 100 mcg - 1 inhaler

genInfo: A seasonal form of allergic rhinitis, the symptoms of which are sneezing, runny nose, red itchy eyes and sometimes sore throat. It is a very common allergic condition where the allergen may be pollen, grasses, animal dander, foods or other chemicals. It may therefore occur throughout the year.
history:
Ask about:
• Runny or blocked nose, sneezing.
• Tight chest or wheeze.
• Watery or itchy eyes.
• Dry, itchy throat.
• Relationship to weather and time of year.
• FHx atopy – asthma, hay fever, eczema

• Occupation; if aircrew refer to MO.
• How much impact do symptoms have on ability to function/do job?
• Have they had this before? Did they take medication?
examination:
Check for:
• Respiratory Rate.
• Temperature
• Chest auscultation: wheeze or reduced breath sounds.
• PEFR if wheezing present.
• Eyes – redness, weeping, discharge?
• Nose – bleeding? Can they breathe through it?
• Throat – swallowing, voice sounds nasal?
management:
Management Basic Level 

Document your history and examination findings and then refer either to a senior medic or medical officer. 

Management Intermediate Level 

Treatment:
• If patient c/o wheeze or SOB; refer to Asthma protocols.
• If no wheeze or SOB; start with nasal irrigation with saline or antihistamine treatment.
• Options - what does patient want?

• Nasal spray antihistamines (from MO or Over the Counter (OTC)) typically faster and more effective treatment than tablets.
• Loratadine 10mg tablet OD (CMT formulary)
• Cetirizine 10mg tablet OD (from MO or OTC).
• Nasal symptoms not controlled by antihistamine; refer for steroid nasal spray or suggest to patient new barrier 
nasal sprays, e.g., Becodefense (only available OTC).

• Eye symptoms not controlled by antihistamines: Sodium Cromoglycate 2% eye drops, 2 drops QDS (CMT formulary). 
• Advise patient that antihistamines and steroid nasal sprays can be bought OTC for their personal first aid kit
• Advise patient to be reviewed after 2-4 weeks if symptoms persist after treatment

Advice: Avoid long grass, recently cut lawns, tree pollen or known allergens where possible.
occHealth:
Occupational Health:

• Avoid allergens where possible.
• If anti-histamines prescribed consider safety critical roles  e.g., driving, operating machinery, use of weapons etc. due to the sedating effect from some antihistamines
refer: Severe symptoms not controlled by medication and affecting lifestyle or work.
highlight:
Note:
• Hay fever may be debilitating and prevent an individual from carrying out basic tasks so treatment is essential.
• Some antihistamines may cause drowsiness and the patient must be advised accordingly.

genInfo: Mouth ulcers are a common complaint in general practice and can be caused by multiple factors including physical or chemical trauma, infection and drug reactions. They are most commonly on the buccal mucosa (lining of the cheek).They are also known as apthous ulcers or canker sores.
history:
Ask about:
• Duration of symptoms.
• Pain.
• Smoking history and alcohol intake.
• Bleeding in the mouth.
• Soreness to tongue.
• Recent illness or stress.
• Dental problems.
• Recent medication such as aspirin.
• What the patient thinks may have caused it.
examination:
Check for:
• Inflammation of affected area.
• Extent of ulceration.
• Neck glands.
• Temperature.
• Examine with white light looking for a round red lesion with white crater.
management:
Management Basic Level 

Document your history and examination findings and then refer to a senior medic or medical officer. 

Management Intermediate Level 

Treatment:
Small Solitary Ulcer:
• Most ulcers heal within 10-14 days without scarring.

• Warm saline (salt water) mouthwashes may relieve pain. Mouthwashes have a mechanical cleansing action and freshens the mouth and should be used at frequent intervals until the discomfort and swelling subside.
• Choline Salicylate 8.7% Gel (Bonjela). 

Multiple Ulcers: 
Choline Salicylate 8.7% Gel (Bonjela) and/or Chlorhexidine 0.2% mouthwash. 

Advice:
• Maintenance of oral hygiene, avoid spicy foods.
• Smoking cessation.
refer: Multiple or enlarging mouth ulcers of more than three weeks duration. Refer to Dental officer to identify if cause may be dental issue.
highlight:
Note:

Mouth ulcers without an obvious physical cause may be a symptom of immunodeficiency, Inflammatory Bowel Disease or Coeliac disease

genInfo: Indigestion describes a range of symptoms from heartburn to severe peptic ulceration. Gastro-Oesophageal Reflux Disease (GORD) is a common condition affecting up to 25% of the population in their lifetime and some have daily symptoms. Smoking, alcohol and obesity may contribute.
history:
Ask about:
• How often and how long they experience symptoms.
• Site of pain epigastric or lower abdomen.
• Radiation of pain left arm indicates possible cardiac nature.
• Exacerbating factors; made worse or relieved by food/antacids.
• Reflux; worse on lying down flat or bending forwards.
• Belching.
• Sweating.
• Vomiting (blood).
• Change in bowel habit.
• Weight loss.
• PMH: previous peptic ulcer, surgery.
• DH: NSAID use, smoking history.
• FH: of GI cancer.
• SH: obesity, smoking, alcohol, coffee/spicy/chocolate
• Stress, anxiety, depression
examination: Examine as for abdominal pain (7.3) including a full set of observations.
management:
Management Basic Level 

Document your history and examination findings and then refer either to a senior medic or medical officer. 

Management Intermediate Level 

Treatment: Gaviscon Advance liquid or tablets. 

Advice:
• Regular meals and smaller meals, avoid alcohol and fatty or spicy foods, coffee, chocolate.
• Prop up the head of the bed if pain on sleeping flat.
• Smoking cessation.
refer:
• PMH Heart disease, breathlessness or radiating pain.
• Persistent symptoms > 48hrs.
• If patient on any medication, particularly NSAIDs.
• Pain or discomfort not resolved by antacids.
• Vomiting; urgent MO RV if blood seen.
highlight:
Note:
Cardiac pain may mimic indigestion, particularly in the elderly. Refer if any radiation, breathlessness or not resolved with antacids.

genInfo: Pain anywhere in the area between rib cage and pubic bone or referred from the groin. Abdominal pain is a relatively frequent presentation in general practice and varies from self-limiting problems to life-threatening illness requiring immediate surgical intervention. The role of the medic is to recognise the potential severity of the condition and refer for diagnosis and management.
history:
Ask about:
• When did the pain start?
• Is there any systemic upset? (fever/headache, dizziness)
• Where on body did the pain start?
• Where is the pain now?
• When were the bowels last opened?
• What makes the pain worse? (e.g. movement, BO, lying still)
•  What makes the pain better? (e.g. movement, BO, lying still)
• Nature of pain? (intermittent/constant/crampy/sharp)
• Associated urinary symptoms? (Frequency / last passed urine / dysuria (pain on urinating) / discharge / blood in urine / pain in groin or testicles
)
• Associated GI symptoms? (Loss of appetite / Nausea/ Vomiting / Diarrhoea / Constipation
)
•  Associated Gynae symptoms? (Date of last period/ Possibility of pregnancy/ depot injection or IUD / previous ectopic / Vaginal discharge or bleeding
)
•  Relevenant Hx (e.g. Foreign travel, contact with others, PMHx of abdominal problems, previous abdominal Rx e.g. appendicectomy)
examination:
Check for:
• Temp, Pulse, RR.
• BP
investigation:
• Urine dipstick
• Pregnancy test - ALL FEMALES
management:
Management Basic and Intermediate Level 

Treatment: Make the patient comfortable whilst awaiting doctor review.
refer: Refer: Prioritise according to symptoms but all cases should be seen quickly by a doctor, particularly testicular pain or PV bleeding.
highlight:
Immediate referral warning signs

• Ectopic pregnancy causes severe lower 
abdominal pain, which may or may not be 
localised to one side. Typically, it occurs
at 6-8 weeks when the patient may not 
even know that she is pregnant. PV 
bleeding may occur late.
• Testicular torsion or ovarian cyst torsion 
cause cramping abdominal pains and are 
both surgical emergencies. Refer
immediately.

genInfo: Constipation is defined as the infrequent or difficult passage of stools. Acute constipation is a change from the individual’s normal habit for more than 4 days and less than 14 days without other symptoms. Chronic constipation is the passage of three stools or less per week with straining, hard stools or sensation of incomplete evacuation. Constipation can develop secondary to haemorrhoids, as a symptom of diverticulosis or irritable bowel syndrome or secondary to pregnancy. Serious, but rare causes include bowel obstruction and bowel cancer.
history:
Ask about:
• Change in bowel habit either frequency or consistency of stool.
• Duration of symptoms.
• Straining at stool.
• BO 3 times a week or less.
• Fluid intake, dehydration.
• Hard motions, “rabbit droppings”. Bristol stool chart; Type 1.
• Abdominal pain, bloating or flatulence.
• Sensation of incomplete evacuation.
• Current medication, especially codeine.
• Blood or mucus in the motion.
examination:
Check for:
• BP, pulse.
• Abdominal distension.
management:
Management Basic Level 

Document your history and examination findings and then refer either to a senior medic or medical officer. 

Management Intermediate Level 

Treatment: Lactulose solution 15ml bd with plenty of water. 

Advice: Ensure adequate fluid intake; 6 - 8 glasses a day. High fibre diet; fresh fruit, vegetables and cereals. Increased exercise may help.
refer:
Referral:
• No response to simple treatment in 48hrs.
• Poor appetite or weight loss.
• Severe abdominal pain or bleeding on defecation.
• Chronic habitual constipation.
• Any prolonged change in bowel habit > 2 weeks.
highlight:
Immediate referral warning signs:

A sudden change in bowel habit, blood or mucus in the stool and weight loss may be indicative of more serious pathology and should be referred urgently.

genInfo:
Rectal problems are common in Service personnel. Presentation is often late because of the embarrassing nature of the problem.
• Haemorrhoids (Piles): Distended veins inside the anal canal which may prolapse on straining and be visible as a soft, grape-like swelling protruding from the anus. They may cause discomfort, itching or bleeding, sometimes profuse.
• Thrombosed external Pile: Very painful, firm, non-reducible pile.
• Anal fissure: Split in the anal skin, often due to passing hard stools. Pain and bleeding on defecation.
• Perianal abscess/fistula: Infection from inside the anus or an ingrowing hair (pilonidal abscess/sinus) resulting in painful swelling (abscess) which may form a fistula.
history:
Ask about:
• Itching/discomfort around anal region.
• Pain around anus increased during defecation.
• Fresh red blood on toilet paper. More than just a trace must be referred to the MO.
examination: Refer to MO for any examination.
management:
Management Basic & Intermediate Level  

Haemorrhoids/Fissures:
Treatment: For known haemorrhoids; Anusol ointment morning, night and after each bowel movement or suppositories.  Keep area clean (consider wet wipes if not able to access regular shower facilities). Some patients may need time out of field exercise when haemorrhoids flare in order to manage cleanliness, bowel opening, and pain

Advice: Avoid constipation and straining at stool by increasing oral fluids and eating a high fibre diet. 

Refer:
• All new cases and those not responding to treatment.


External Thrombosed Pile/Perianal abscess/fistula:
Refer all cases.
refer:
Haemorrhoids/Fissures:
• All new cases and those not responding to treatment.  

External Thrombosed Pile/Perianal abscess/fistula:
Refer all cases.
highlight:
Immediate referral warning signs:

Bowel cancer can occur in young people. Anyone with a prolonged change in bowel habits needs referral.

genInfo: Diarrhoea and vomiting is usually a selflimiting condition, often related to eating food contaminated with bacteria or viruses or it may be a symptom of other conditions such as appendicitis. Food poisoning may be obvious from the history if the patient vomits within hours of eating the suspect food, which is often chicken or dairy produce. Frequent liquid stools are passed, often associated with abdominal cramps and nausea.
history:
Ask about:
• Abdominal pain: location, intensity and nature (colicky, relieved by bowel motion or vomiting).
• Diarrhoea: frequency, blood and mucus. Use Bristol Stool Chart. 
• Vomiting: frequency, blood or “coffee grounds”.
• Other individuals affected, shared meals, fast food.
• History of recent foreign travel.
• When last passed urine; indication of dehydration state.

D+V Proforma Questions
When did the diarrhoea/vomiting start? .
Diarrhoea Frequency (episodes in past 24 Hrs): 
Blood Yes/No Mucus Yes/No?
Stool Type (use Bristol Stool Chart) 
Vomiting Frequency: (episodes in past 24 Hrs): 
Blood: Yes/No Coffee Grounds Yes/No?
Relevant History Foreign travel/ Contact with others with similar/ Suspect food
Systemic Upset Headache/ Fever/ Dizziness/ Photophobia/ Neck Stiffness Yes/No?
Fluid intake past 24hrs  (in Litres)
On OCP Yes/No?
Abdominal Examination:
Pain: Yes/No?
When did it start?
Type e.g. colicky, relieved by passing stool etc.
Where is it?
Bloating Yes/No?
Bowel Sounds Present/Increased/Decreased?
examination:
Check for:
• Temp, Pulse and BP. Consider blood sugar.
• Abdominal examination; note bowel sounds, distension and tenderness.
investigation:
• Stool sample for culture if appropriate.
• Urine dipstick
management:
Management Basic Level 

Document your history and examination findings and then refer to a senior medic or medical officer. 

Management Intermediate Level 

Treatment: 
Mild and symptoms less than 24 hours:
• Drink clear fluids only for 24 hours.
• Anti-diarrhoeals should only be given for specific travel or operational reasons.
• Consider rehydration salts, such as Dioralyte, if unable to eat. 

Advice:
• Hygiene precautions.
• Reintroduce foods gradually after 24 hrs if symptoms are settling. Avoid milk/dairy products initially.
• Those taking the Oral Contraceptive Pill must be advised to use alternative contraceptive measures but continue with their OCP.
occHealth:
Public Health:
• Food handlers must be assessed free from infection before returning to work.
• Complete FMed 85.
• Refer for admission to MRS to prevent spread of infection when living in shared accommodation.
• Consider C chit up to 3/7 to allow 24 hrs post infection.
refer:
• Significant dehydration.
• Symptoms persisting after 48 hours of treatment.
• Elevated temperature or recurring diarrhoea.
• Recent overseas travel to countries where dysentery or cholera is endemic.
• Blood or mucus in the stool or blood or “coffee grounds” vomitus.
highlight:
Immediate referral warning signs:

Severe vomiting without bowel motions may indicate abdominal obstruction.

genInfo:
Threadworm (pinworm) infection is the most common form of helminthic parasite infestation in humans. The roundworms measure up to 13mm in length and look like threads of cotton. 
Diagnosis is often made by seeing them moving in stools. The most common symptom is severe itching around the anus, particularly at night. In females, the genital area can also be involved and may present with an itchy vulva.

They are highly contagious.
history:
Ask about:
• Itching around the bottom (or vulva in women)
• Threadworms seen in stool or around anus.
• Disturbed sleep and irritability
• Contacts with confirmed infection or similar symptoms.
examination: Nil
investigation:
*Only do investigations if the diagnosis is 
uncertain*

The Sellotape test: the patient is asked to stick sellotape around anal margin first thing in the morning, before wiping or bathing, May need 3 consecutive mornings to confirm diagnosis to pick up eggs which are laid on the skin around the anus overnight. Stick the tape to a microscope slide and send to lab. 

Alternatively wipe the anal margin with a cotton bud and send to lab. 

Stool examination is not recommended
management:
Management Basic Level 

Document your history and examination findings and then refer to a medical officer. 

Management Intermediate Level Treatment:
• Mebendazole 100mg single dose (unless contraindicated).
• Consider treating all household contacts and service personnel in close shared accommodation as threadworms are highly transmissible and eggs may live outside the body for some time.
• A second dose may be required after two weeks if infection persists. 

Advice:
• Wear pyjama bottoms at night to avoid anal scratching.
• Follow good hygiene, taking particular care to wash hands thoroughly after contact with anus.
• Keep fingernails trimmed short.
• Wash every morning, including perianal area, to remove eggs from skin.
• Change bed linen and nightwear daily for several days after treatment
• Hot washing/drying cycles or bedding and clothing will kill threadworm eggs. 
• Thoroughly dust and vacuum (including vacuuming mattresses) and clean the bathroom surfaces, washing the cleaning cloth frequently in hot water.
• Note that if infection recurs, this is usually due to re-infection rather than failure of anti-helminthic medication.
occHealth:
Public Health
• Good hygiene must be followed to prevent re-infection.
• Food handlers are not to work with foodstuffs until reassessed free from infection.
refer:
Refer:
• Pregnant servicewomen.
• Patients with persistent anal itching.

genInfo: Infection of any part of the urinary tract from kidney to urethra. Infection of the bladder is called cystitis. Infections are more common in women because of the shorter urethra.
history:
Ask about:
• Frequency of urination (micturition) but small amounts.
• Pain on urination (dysuria).
• Waking at night to urinate (nocturia).

• Cloudy or foul smelling urine.
• Blood in the urine (haematuria).
• Vaginal/urethral discharge.
• Irritation / rashes.

• Fever and vomiting.
• Suprapubic, loin or groin pain.
• PMH: Previous UTI, renal stones, Pelvic Inflammatory Disease (PID), Sexually Transmitted Infections (STI), Diabetes.
• LMP, pregnancy.
• SH: Symptomatic sexual partner.
examination:
Check for: Temp, pulse and BP.

Examine for flank or suprapubic tenderness.
investigation:
• Urine dipstick and keep sample for culture.
• Pregnancy test if appropriate.
management:
Management Basic Level 

Document your history and examination findings and then refer either to a senior medic or medical officer. 

Management Intermediate Level 

Treatment:
• Pain relief. Paracetamol or if preferred and suitable, ibuprofen.
• Consider LD B chit for 1-2/7 to excuse physical activity. 

Advice:
• Increase oral fluid intake.
• Double voiding of bladder to prevent urinary stasis.
• Voiding after sexual intercourse.
• Good peri-anal hygiene, avoid bubble bath, vaginal douches, tight underclothes and synthetic materials.
occHealth:
Public Health:
Consider sexually transmitted infection and refer to Genitourinary Medicine (GUM) clinic if appropriate.
refer:
• Female Patients whose symptoms do not improve within 24 hrs of starting treatment.
• All men with UTI.
• Pregnant women.
• Diabetics.
• Frequent attacks.
highlight:
Immediate referral warning signs:

Fever, nausea and vomiting or flank pain suggest kidney infection (Pyelonephritis) which requires urgent referral.

genInfo: Inflammation of the glans penis. Inflammation may be due to poor hygiene, particularly in uncircumcised males, overzealous washing, STIs, use of fragranced soap/shower gels or diabetes mellitus.
history:
Ask about:
• Itching/soreness.
• Erythema and irritation of the glans penis.
• Discharge - distinguish from urethral discharge.
• Sexual history, including symptoms in partner.
examination: Check for: Check the foreskin and glans.
investigation:
• Dipstick urine for glucose.

management:
Management Basic Level 

Document your history and examination findings and then refer to a senior medic or medical officer.

Treatment: Clotrimazole 1% cream for fungal infections. 

Advice: Good hygiene.

Public Health:
Advice regarding sexual health, including use of condoms. Opportunistic Chlamydia screening if appropriate.
refer:

genInfo: Pain in scrotum due to infective and non infective conditions. Testicular pain may be due to trauma or infection (epididymoorchitis). All testicular pain must be seen by a doctor because of the serious consequences of missing a testicular torsion.
history:
Ask about:
• Testicular pain, duration and onset.
• Swelling, erythema or tenderness of testicle or epididymis.
• Unilateral or bilateral.
• Dysuria, frequency and haematuria.
• Urethral discharge.
• Fever.
• Abdominal pain, nausea or vomiting.
• History of sexually transmitted infection (STI)
• PMH: Maldescent/surgery.
• Recent trauma.
examination: Check for: Temperature, pulse.
management:
Management Basic & Intermediate Level 

Document your history and examination findings and then immediate referral to a medical officer.
occHealth:
Public Health:
The commonest infecting organism in young men presenting with epididymo-orchitis is Chlamydia. Partner investigation and treatment should be carried out by the Genitourinary Medicine clinic.
refer: Document your history and examination findings and then immediate referral to a medical officer.
highlight:
Immediate referral warning signs:

 Testicular torsion is twisting of the cord supporting the testicle causing impairment of its blood supply. This is a surgical emergency and requires immediate referral.

genInfo: Infections transmitted by unprotected sexual intercourse. Sexually transmitted infections are common and 30% of those presenting will have more than one infection. When possible all STI should be referred to a Genitourinary Medicine (GUM) clinic where they are able to test for a range of conditions, provide rapid diagnosis and other confidential services such as contact tracing and counselling. STI may be serious and some are potentially life threatening. Failure to treat infections may result in many more people becoming infected and complications such as infertility and malignancy.
history:
Ask about:
• Rash or irritation.
• Sores or blisters on vagina, penis or around anus.
• Pain on urination (dysuria).
• Vaginal/urethral discharge.
• Frequency of micturition.
• Testicular swelling.
• Pain on sexual intercourse
• Fever and vomiting.
• Suprapubic pain.
• Pregnancy.
• PMH: Previous STI.
• PMH: Symptomatic sexual partner.
• Prostitutes/sex workers.
examination: Refer to MO for examination.
investigation:
Urine dipstick and send sample for culture. 

Pregnancy test for females if indicated.
management:
Management Basic & Intermediate Level 

Document your history and refer to medical officer.
occHealth:
Public Health:
• Contact tracing through GUM clinic.
• Prevention by wearing a condom and practicing Safer Sex.
• Opportunistic chlamydia screening.
refer: Document your history and refer to medical officer.
highlight:
Note:

STI remain high throughout the world despite medical advances and may be particularly prevalent in areas of conflict on operations.

genInfo:
Menstrual issues generally present in the following ways:
• Abnormal bleeding. Any change from the baseline in either duration, frequency or regularity.
• Heavy bleeding. Increase in bleeding from the normal. 
• Painful periods
• Infrequent or absent periods compared to the normal

Menstruation (average values):
• Duration (bleeding): 3-8 days, pain and other symptoms can last longer
• Frequency: every 21-35 days
• Regularity: Cycles are usually at regular intervals, if they are completely unpredictable this can be a sign of an underlying disorder.
• Volume: Any changes are relative to the individual’s normal but on average only one method of protection (pad/tampon etc.) should be needed and these should not need to be changed any more often than every 4 hours.
• Ends with menopause ~51 years old 

Sanitary items for menstrual bleeding include pads (reusable and disposable), tampons (with or without applicators), panty liners, cups, absorbable menstrual pants and tights. 
Deployed service personnel should have access to sanitary items via the logistics chain.
history:
History
Ask about:
• The first day of the last menstrual period (LMP), and what this was like
• Normal cycle length and duration 
• Other symptoms associated with periods e.g. nausea, vomiting, pain, breast tenderness, headaches etc.
• Effect on work and daily life
• Possibility of pregnancy 
• Contraception used (coils, implant, pills etc.)
examination:
Exam/ investigations:
• Pulse and blood pressure
• Abdominal exam 
• Pregnancy test (if absent periods)
management: Document your history and then refer to a medical officer if any significant changes or concerns
refer:
Discuss with MO:
• Absent bleeding/ missed period if unexpected
• Change in cycle 
• Period changes in women >40 years -Urgently refer to an MO:
• Bleeding after sex 
• Unexpected bleeding between periods
• Bleeding in post-menopausal women (>40yrs old AND 12+ months without a 
period)
• Suspicion of pregnancy or positive pregnancy test

genInfo:
Pelvic pain in women can have many causes. 
For acute pain also see [7.3 Abdominal Pain protocol] for further questions. Ongoing pelvic pain that persists outside of menstruation should be discussed with an MO.

A common cause of acute pelvic pain is menstrual cramps of uterine origin (dysmenorrhoea). It may be divided into
primary dysmenorrhoea which is normal “period pains” without abnormal pathologyand secondary dysmenorrhoea due to identifiable conditions such as endometriosis or ovarian cysts.
history:
Primary: 
• Cramping lower abdominal pains, relatively common in young women, experienced on the first 1-2 days of menstruation.

Other questions to ask:
• Menstrual history; age of onset, regular/irregular cycles, duration and amount of bleeding.
• Pain timing; at the same time as the bleeding and other period symptoms or before the period?
• Location of pain (central over the bladder/womb or off to one side?)
• Pain when having sex
• New period pain commonly, but not always, over 40 years old.
• History of pelvic inflammatory/sexuallytransmitted disease.
• UTI symptoms.
• Vaginal discharge
• Last Menstrual period (LMP).
• Contraception used.
• Possibility of pregnancy.
• Obstetric history, including miscarriages.
examination:
• Temp, pulse and BP.
• Abdominal exam

Note: Intimate exams should only be performed by an MO.
management:
Management Basic Level 

Document your history and then refer to a medical officer if any significant changes or concerns. 

Management Intermediate Level 

Treatment: Ibuprofen 400mg tablets 3 x daily with food. Light duties if necessary. B chit 1/7 up to max 3/7 then refer to MO for further guidance. 

Advice: Rest in comfortable position with knees drawn up. Hot water bottle or hot bath may be helpful.
refer:
Refer:
• Pain related to having sex
• Pain occurring at a different time to the bleeding e.g. just before bleeding starts or mid-cycle (could be ovarian cyst or endometriosis)
highlight:
Note:
Beware of ectopic pregnancy or miscarriage

Refer urgently:
• Any pain that is off to one side of the pelvis/abdomen (could be ovarian cyst, pelvic inflammatory disease 
or ectopic pregnancy) 
• Any pain associated with a positive pregnancy test (could be ectopic pregnancy or miscarriage)
• If menstruation is late (could be pregnancy)
• Any patient who does not respond to mild analgesia

genInfo: Heavy Menstrual Bleeding (Menorrhagia) is heavy but regular menstrual bleeding. This often affects the quality of life and very heavy blood loss may result in iron deficiency anaemia, particularly in vegetarians or those with poor diets.
history:
Ask about:
• Menstrual history; age of onset, regular/irregular cycles,  normal for them.
• Duration of bleeding.
• Amount of bleeding; frequency of changing pads/tampons or flooding (bleeding through products on to clothes) and if there are any blood clots.
• Pain, location of and when this happens in relation to the bleeding.
• History of Pelvic inflammatory/sexually transmitted disease.
• Contraception, especially IUCD (e.g. Mirena or copper coil) and possibility of pregnancy.
• Obstetric history particularly recent delivery, miscarriage or Termination of Pregnancy (TOP).
examination:
Check for:
• Temp, Pulse (rapid in severe anaemia), BP.
• Pallor (indication of anaemia).
• Abdominal exam

Note: Intimate exams should only be performed by an MO.
management:
Management Basic Level 

Document your history and examination findings and then refer either to a senior medic or medical officer. 

Management Intermediate Level

• As above.
• Light duties B chit 1-3/7 if necessary whilst waiting for MO appointment, if no red flags.
refer:
Refer urgently if recent positive pregnancy test

Refer any heavy menstrual bleeding with pain to a MO urgently
highlight:
Note:

Beware of ectopic pregnancy or miscarriage.

Refer urgently if recent positive pregnancy test
