genInfo: The primary symptom of thrush is vaginal itching and abnormal cheese-like or watery vaginal discharge. The most common organism is the yeast Candida Albicans. Thrush may occur after a course of antibiotics, during pregnancy or when using the oral contraceptive pill. If sexually active, both the patient and partner should be treated simultaneously to prevent re-infection, even if the partner has no symptoms.
history:
Ask about:
• Amount of discharge.
• Colour; white/curd.
• Odour – usually none.

• Itching – usually external on the vulva.
• Abdominal or pelvic pain – not usual with thrush.
• Timing with menstrual cycle – can occur for some people at set times of the cycle.
• PMH: Previous episodes.
examination: Examination only by a trained nurse or medical officer.
investigation: A charcoal swab (black handle) can be taken by the patient (put into the vagina and do a couple of circles) and sent for MC&S
management:
Management Basic Level 

Document your history and then refer either to a senior medic or medical officer. 

Management Intermediate Level 
Treatment:
• Clotrimazole 500mg pessary insert at night 
• OR Fluconazole 150mg capsule single dose.
• AND Clotrimazole 1% cream twice daily for use on the vulva.


Advice:
• Avoid nylon underwear, tight trousers.
• Avoid bubble bath, vaginal douches.
• Avoid biological washing powders.
• Aim to pass urine after sexual intercourse.
• Opportunistic sexual health advice.
refer:
Refer:
• If any change in bleeding pattern, any pain or any symptoms that are not usual with thrush.
• Recurrence within month of previous treatment may be indicative of a systemic problem e.g. diabetes.
• Any episode that does not respond to the treatment above.
• Any risk of STI.


 Diabetic and pregnant patients must be referred.
highlight:
Immediate referral warning signs:

 Diabetic and pregnant patients must be referred.

genInfo: Breast conditions include benign or malignant breast lumps, cyclical or non-cyclical breast pain, nipple changes and discharge/bleeding or mastitis/abscesses. Breast cancer may also present with skin or nipple changes, changes in the size, shape or colour of the breast or discharge or bleeding from the nipple as well as a lump.
history:
Ask about:
• Lump: New or altered lump in the breast or axillae. Is the lump painful, mobile? Does the individual regularly check their breasts?
• Skin changes: Puckering or dimpling (peau d’orange) of the skin. Any rash, colour or temperature changes.
• Nipple changes: Rash or crusting or the nipple, nipple inversion, nipple discharge or bleeding. 
• Pain: Cyclical pain caused by hormone fluctuations in the menstrual cycle where breasts can feel lumpy, painful and tender a week or so before menstruation. Non cyclical breast pain is not linked to the menstrual cycle and may have a variety of causes including other benign breast 
conditions, injury or surgery to the breast, medications or having larger breasts. Description of the pain; site, character, radiation any relieving or exacerbating factors. 
• Menstrual history; age of onset, regular/irregular cycles, amount and duration of bleeding and last menstrual period.
• Obstetric history including breastfeeding. 
• Medication including any contraception or other hormones, anti-depressants, herbal remedies.
• Family history of breast cancer especially in first degree relatives
• Previous breast history; surgery, previous breast conditions/lumps, previous breast cancer.
examination: MO only
management:
Management Basic Level

Document history and observation findings 
and refer to MO.

Management Intermediate Level

Treatment: Ibuprofen 400mg tablets 3 x a day with/after food for breast pain. LDs up to 3/7 if required until MO review
refer: Same day to MO

genInfo: The perimenopause is start of the decline of female hormones culminating in the menopause and cessation of a woman’s periods. During this time, women can experience a multitude of symptoms. A change to the menstrual pattern including cycle length and volume of blood loss will also be experienced, for some this can mean heavier more painful periods. Menopause is the end of menstruation and occurs at an average age of 51 years, perimenopause symptoms can last for many years after the menopause.
history:
Ask about:
• Menstrual history; age of onset, change in cycle length, duration and amount of blood loss.
• Vasomotor symptoms; hot flushes or night sweats. May be associated with excessive sweating, palpitations or anxiety
• Cognitive impairment or mood disorders; anxiety, mood swings, irritability, low mood, poor concentration and memory and difficulties multi-tasking with a reduced quality of life.
• Sleep disturbance; due to vasomotor symptoms but may also be due to mood disorder or primary sleep disturbance.
• Urogenital symptoms and altered sexual function; vulvovaginal irritation, discomfort, burning, itching and/or dryness; dyspareunia (pain during sex), dysuria (pain on urination), urinary frequency and urgency, recurrent lower urinary tract infections, loss of sexual desire and libido.
• Joint and muscles pains.
• Headaches.
• Fatigue.
• Medications including contraception.
• Impact of symptoms on job role and home life
examination: • Temp, pulse, BP and BMI
management:
Management Basic Level

Document your history and examination and 
refer to MO

Management Intermediate Level

Consider Light Duties if appropriate or required for up to 3/7 until routine MO review

history:
Ask about:
• Urinary function –frequency/pain/associated symptoms or activities
• Bowel function – severe constipation/ diarrhoea/ incontinence 
• Sexual function – pain
• A feeling of heaviness or something dragging in the vagina (prolapse)
• Current medications
• Diet (alcohol, caffeine, foods high in acid -tomatoes, grapefruit, spicy foods)
• Pregnancy & childbirth 
• Previous surgery
examination: Examination only by a trained nurse or medical officer
investigation:
Dipstick urine and send MSU sample for 
MC&S

Document your history and refer to a medical 
officer.

Advice:
• Avoid trigger foods & drinks
• Exercises to strengthen muscles (pelvic floor exercises)
• Manage fluid intake - limit fluids before bedtime; aim to ensure well hydrated as concentrated urine can worsen symptoms, but over-hydration will increase requirement to pass urine.
• Stop smoking
refer: Refer: All cases
highlight:
RED FLAGS
• Severe pain while passing urine

condition: Cervical  vaginal and vulval inflammatory diseases
genInfo:
There are multiple causes and presentations of vulval and vaginal lesions. Taking a good history is key for diagnosis and referral.

Some causes and their symptoms include: 
STIs 
– syphilis (painless chancre – a small sore), genital warts (fleshy growths, may itch), 
Herpes Simplex virus (small, painful blisters or sores)

Cysts 
– Pilonidal, Bartholin, Skene Ducts (small painless cysts which can become infected and painful – pealike)

Vulval cancers 
- can present as sores/lumps/unusual pigmentation

Vaginal and Anal prolapses
history:
Ask about: 
• Pain in or around the lesion 
• Itching 
• Lumps or bumps 
• Bleeding 
• Abdominal or pelvic pain. 
• History of lesion – how long it has been there and if it has changed
• PMH: Previous episodes. 
• Sexual health history 
• Self-treatment they have tried 
• Current medications 
• Pregnancy
examination: Examination only by a trained nurse or medical officer.
investigation: If any - if not enter Nil
management:
Management Basic Level
Document your history and refer to a medical 
officer.

Management Intermediate Level 
• Pain management and analgesia as required
refer: Refer: All cases

genInfo: Pregnancy lasts for approx 40 weeks as the developing foetus grows in the uterus. The early stages may be accompanied by morning sickness, breast tenderness and enlargement and an increase in appetite. These symptoms are due to hormonal changes.
history:
Ask about:

• PV Bleeding.

.
• Tiredness.

investigation:

occHealth:
Occupational Health
• The working environment can have an impact on the developing foetus which must be assessed when taking the history.
• Pregnant service personnel must be downgraded to protect them and the foetus.
refer: Arrangements should be made for the soldier to be seen by a MO as soon as possible, particularly on operations.

Arrangements should be made for the soldier to be seen by a MO as soon as possible, particularly on operations.

genInfo:
There are two important complications relating to early pregnancy that may present in Servicewomen. 

Early pregnancycomplications often present with pelvic pain and/or bleeding 6+ weeks after the last menstrual period. At this stage the pregnancy may not be known about.

Ectopic pregnancies are pregnancies that have implanted outside the uterus. 

Miscarriages are the loss of a pregnancy prior to 24 weeks gestation.
history:
Ask about:
• Date of last menstrual period.
• Pain – one sided makes ectopic pregnancy more likely. This is an emergency.
• PV Bleeding/ discharge – with pain could be ectopic or miscarriage
• Possibility of pregnancy / unprotected sex / positive pregnancy test
• Contraception 
• Current occupation.
• Drug history.
examination:
Check for:

management:

If positive pregnancy test or suspicion of pregnancy with pain and/or bleeding to refer urgently to MO.

Bed down until discussed with MO

Consider the woman’s wellbeing when discussing these issues

genInfo:
Unprotected sex increases the risk of pregnancy and exposure to sexually transmitted infections. Any instances where emergency contraception is required should be discussed with an MO urgently. 

The emergency contraception tablet included in the 501 module is Ulipristal Acetate 
(EllaOne)

genInfo: Pain or spasm in neck muscle occurring either spontaneously (wry neck) or after an injury. Neck pain is very common, often related to posture, occupation or trauma. Neck sprain or “whiplash” injuries frequently occur in road traffic accidents when a car is shunted from behind. Most are self-limiting but may persist for several weeks.
history:
Ask about:
• Duration, location, nature, onset, radiation of pain.
• Headache.
• Numbness/paraesthesia/weakness.
• Trauma, particularly falls from above shoulder height or RTC.
• Sore throat, fever or rash may indicate infection such as meningitis.
• PMH: Previous episodes.
• SH: Occupation.
• DH: Medication.

Note: Use the Injury Causation Template
examination:
Check for:
• Flexion, extension, lateral flexion and rotation of neck.
• Tenderness.
• Examine both upper limbs and check neurological function.
• Cervical lymphadenopathy.
• Temp to exclude fever if no history of trauma.

Note: Use the Injury Causation Template
management:
Management Basic Level 

Document your history and examination findings and then refer to a senior medic or medical officer. 

Management Intermediate Level 

Minor injury (if neck is mobile and no radiation of pain):
Treatment:
• Reassure; most neck pain resolves without treatment.
• Paracetamol 2 x 500mg tablets qds or Ibuprofen 400mg tablet tds with food. 

Advice:
• Mobility exercises within pain free ROM.
• Warm packs.
occHealth:
• Light duties Max 3/7 then needs MO appointment depending on occupation.
• Workplace/DSE assessment may be required.
refer:
• Refer to MO.
• Physiotherapy may be helpful using manipulation and traction to relieve pain.
highlight:
Immediate referral warning signs:

 Refer immediately any patient with significant pain with immobility and/or radiation of pain. Photophobia or fever may indicate infection such as malaria or meningitis so refer immediately.

Note: Use the Injury Causation Template

genInfo: Pain in back muscles or spine due to posture or injury. 70% of people in developed countries will experience back pain at some time in their lives. Most are self-limiting and 90% recover within 6 weeks. About 5% develop chronic pain.
history:
Ask about:
• Duration, location, nature, onset, radiation and progression of pain.
• Numbness, weakness or paraesthesia.
• Changes in bladder or bowel function such as urine retention.
• Trauma, particularly violent injury such as RTC.
• Pain on cough or sneeze.
• Pregnancy.
• PMH: Previous episodes.
• SH: Occupation and how the back pain is affecting ability to do job.
• Fever, weight loss or other illness.
• DH: Medication taken for pain or other such as steroids.

Note: Use the Injury Causation Template
examination:
Check for:
• Record functional ability, rotation, flexion, extension.
• Radiation of pain into buttocks or back of legs.
• Examine both lower limbs and check neurological function.
• Straight Leg Raises (SLR) Left vs Right.
• Temperature.

Note: Use the Injury Causation Template
management:
Management Basic Level 
Document your history and examination findings and refer to a senior medic or medical officer. 

Management Intermediate Level 

Treatment: Minor injury (if mobile and no radiation of pain), then:
• Reassure; most back pain is mechanical and resolves without treatment.
• Paracetamol 2 x 500mg tablets qds or Ibuprofen 400mg tablet tds with food.
• May required B chit for 1-2/7 heavy lifting, weighted runs, tabs and competitive sports. 

Advice:
• Mobility exercises, weight loss if appropriate.
• Attention to posture, especially sitting.
• Warm packs may help.
occHealth:
Occupational Health:

• Light duties as appropriate depending on occupation.
• Workplace/DSE assessment may be required.
refer:
Mild Pain:
Refer to MO on normal sick parade. Physiotherapy may be helpful using manipulation and exercises to relieve pain.

Moderate to Severe: 
Refer to MO.
highlight:
Immediate referral warning signs:

If immobile or any weakness or bladder symptoms refer to MO immediately.

Note: Use the Injury Causation Template

genInfo: Pain or stiffness in muscles and ligaments of shoulder girdle. Serious conditions, such as a dislocation may be obvious and should be dealt with as an emergency. Chronic conditions often require careful diagnosis and long-term treatment.
history:
Ask about:
• Duration, location, nature, onset, radiation of pain.
• Trauma.
• Mechanism of injury.
• Instability.
• Tenderness.
• PMH: Previous episodes.
• DH: Medication.
examination:
Check for:
• Compare both sides and check for deformity such as squaring of shoulder in dislocation.
• Range of shoulder movement; flexion, extension, abduction, adduction, internal and external rotation.
• Muscle wasting.
• Paraesthesia or altered sensation in arm or hand.
investigation: Discuss with the MO if obviously dislocated or fractured or high index of suspicion as may require an x-ray.
management:
Management Basic Level 

Document your history and examination findings and then refer either to a senior medic or medical officer. 

Management Intermediate Level 

Treatment: 
• Rest with a sling to relieve pain. Paracetamol 2 x 500mg tablets qds or Ibuprofen 400mg tablet tds with food.
• LD B chit for max 3/7 whilst waiting for MO appointment. Recommend the patient does exercises appropriate to injury. 

Advice: 
For minor injuries active exercises hourly in pain free range.
occHealth:
Occupational Health:

• Light duties as appropriate depending on occupation.
• Workplace/DSE assessment may be required.
refer: Depending on severity.
highlight:
Immediate referral warning signs:

Shoulder dislocations are extremely painful and must be dealt with as an emergency.

genInfo: The wrists and hands are very vulnerable to injury and difficult to diagnose accurately. Take a good history but refer to a doctor early as the consequences of missing injuries such as a scaphoid fracture may be serious.
history:
Ask about:
• Mechanism of injury.
• Duration, location, nature, onset and radiation of pain.
• Bruising or swelling.
• Loss of function.
• Deformity.
• Paraesthesia, numbness or weakness.
examination:
Check for:
• Compare two sides against each other for small changes.
• Tenderness.
• Swelling and warmth.
• Deformity, muscle wasting.
• Loss of function; passive and active movements and power.
• Check circulation and neurological function.
• Examine neck for range of movement and tenderness.
investigation: Discuss with the MO if obviously deformed or high index of suspicion from the history as may require an x-ray.
management:
Management Basic Level 

Document your history and examination findings and refer to a medical officer. 

Management Intermediate Level 

Treatment:
• Splints and a sling may relieve pain. Ice for 10-15 mins if swollen.
• Paracetamol 2 x 500mg tablets qds or Ibuprofen 400mg tablet tds with food.
occHealth:
Occupational Health:

• Light duties depending on occupation. B chit up to max 3/7 whilst waiting for a MO appointment to determine future management and further light duties.
• DSE/WPA may be required if recurrence of symptoms.
• Consider vibration injury.
refer:
• All hand injuries with lacerations should be seen urgently by a doctor to exclude tendon/nerve injury.
• All suspected fractures.
highlight:
Immediate referral warning signs:

Scaphoid fractures can be easily missed and are often diagnosed as a ligament sprain. Anyone who falls and lands on an outstretched hand and complains of pain around the wrist should be assumed to have a scaphoid fracture and referred to the MO.

genInfo: Knee pain is a complex area. Suspected ligament or cartilage injury should always be referred to a Doctor. Anterior knee pain is often from the patellofemoral joint (PFJ) and associated soft tissues. Patella tendon problems and iliotibial band syndrome are less common and can be either acute or chronic.
history:
Ask about:
• Duration, location, nature, onset, radiation and progression of pain.
• Instability, giving way, locking.
• Trauma, mechanism of injury.
• How quickly swelling occurred after injury.
• Unilateral or bilateral pain.
• DH Medication.
• PMH: Previous episodes.
• SH: Occupation, include changes in training pattern or footwear.
examination:
Check for:
• Range of knee movement, flexion, extension.
• Muscle wasting.
• Swelling, effusion.
• Tenderness.
• Ligament stability
management:
Management Basic Level 

Document your history and examination findings and then refer either to a senior medic or medical officer. 

Management Intermediate Level 

Treatment:
• For acute strains and sprains seen within the first 48 hrs use the PRICE approach:
• Pain Relief: Paracetamol 2 x 500mg tablets qds or Ibuprofen 400mg tablet tds with food.
• Rest: Rest the affected limb as much as possible, consider crutches if unable to fully weight bear. Light duties.
• Ice: Cool with ice pack for 20 minutes, every 2-3 hrs.
• Compression: Strap and support with crepe bandage or tubigrip.
• Elevation: Use a chair or pillows. Keep the knee as straight as pain will allow.
• Crutches may be required initially but patient should be strongly encouraged to walk as normally as possible whilst using the crutches.
occHealth:
Occupational Health:

Consider LD B chit 1-2/7.
refer:
• With swelling.
• A hot, swollen, painful knee may be ‘septic arthritis’.
• With loss of flexion more than 90 degrees and/or unable to fully extend the knee.
• Unable to fully weight bear.
• Consider referral for long standing knee pain that is affecting function.
highlight:
Immediate referral warning signs:

 Immediate swelling at the time of injury may indicate a significant ligament or cartilage tear and should be seen by the doctor immediately.

Additionally, any history of locking or knee instability needs referral to the MO.

genInfo: Ankle injuries are very common in military training. Some protection is afforded by wearing boots but walking over uneven ground, especially at night, carrying weight often results in ankle sprains.
history:
Ask about:
• Mechanism of injury.
• How quickly swelling occurred after injury.
• Duration, location, nature, onset, radiation and progression of pain.
• Unilateral/bilateral.
• PMH Previous episodes; repeated inversion injuries.
• SH: Occupation, include changes in training pattern or footwear.
examination:
Check for:
• Functional ability as the patient comes into the room.
• Deformity, swelling or bruising.
• Range of ankle movement; plantar/dorsiflexion, eversion, inversion.
• Ligament instability.
• Pulses, note if weak or absent.
investigation:
Ottowa ankle rules: X-rays are only required if there is bony pain in the malleolar zone and any one of the following:
• Bone tenderness along the distal 6 cm of the posterior edge of the tibia or tip of the medial malleolus.
• Bone tenderness along the distal 6 cm of the posterior edge of the fibula or tip of the lateral malleolus.
• An inability to bear weight both immediately and in the emergency department for four steps. Fill out an X-ray request form for the MO if Ottowa ankle rules, above, are complied with.
management:
Management Basic and Intermediate Level

Treatment: 
For acute strains and sprains seen within the first 48 hrs use the PRICE approach:
• Pain Relief: Paracetamol 2 x 500mg tablets qds or Ibuprofen 400mg tablet tds with food.
• Rest: Rest the affected limb as much as possible, consider crutches if unable to fully weight bear. Light duties.
• Ice: Cool with ice pack for 20 minutes, every 2-3 hrs.
• Compression: Strap and support with crepe bandage or tubigrip.
• Elevation: Use a chair or pillows.
• Crutches may be required initially but patient should be strongly encouraged to walk as normally as possible whilst using the crutches. 

Advice:
• Gentle Mobility exercises and weight bear as tolerated.
• Practice balance exercises regularly on injured leg as soon as can fully weight bear.
• The foot should be elevated as much as possible when at rest.
occHealth:
Occupational Health:

Light duties as appropriate depending on severity of injury and occupation. Max 3/7 whilst awaiting an appointment with the MO to cionsider future management.
refer: Doctor review if patient unable to fully weight bear or not responding to treatment after 24-48hrs.
highlight:
Note:

Ligament injuries take approx 6 weeks to recover.

genInfo:
Lower leg pain is commonly referred to as “shin splints” but there are several, definable conditions that require different treatment. 
The diagnosis is made mostly on the history, taking careful note of the nature of the pain and when it occurs in relation to exercise:

• Compartment Syndrome. Local burning pain and tenderness that builds up gradually during exercise and may persist as a cramping pain after the end of the session. The muscle bulk may feel tight and tender to touch.

• Medial Tibial Stress Syndrome. Periostitis; inflammation of the muscle attachments along the medial tibial border. Pain is felt on exercise, particularly running up hills but stops as soon as training ends.

• Tibial Stress Fracture. Pain on each impact, relieved by rest initially but may cause constant pain when severe.
history:
Ask about:
• Trauma. Mechanism of injury.
• Duration, location, nature, onset, radiation, relation to impact and stopping exercise.
• Any change in normal exercise routine or running conditions such as hard surfaces, carrying weight, changes in footwear or running in boots.
• Unilateral/bilateral.
• PMH: Previous episodes.
• DH: Medication.
examination:
Check for:
• Swelling, warmth and bruising.
• Tenderness or tight muscle, point on tibia or percussion of tibia.
• Numbness or paraesthesia (including first web space on foot).
• Muscle weakness or foot drop.
• Pulses.
• Investigation.
• Pain on hopping indicates Stress fracture not MTSS.
management:
Management Basic Level 

Document your history and examination findings and then refer either to a senior medic or medical officer. 

Management Intermediate Level 

Treatment: Paracetamol 2 x 500mg tablets qds or Ibuprofen 400mg tablet tds with food. 

Advice:
• Review training program and footwear with advice from the Physio or Remedial Instructor. They may recommend stretches and ice cube massage along painful area of shin.
• Gradual return to training once pain free, with graded impact training. The MO may need to refer for a Podiatry opinion.
occHealth:
Occupational Health:

Stress fractures in particular may require many weeks or months off impact exercise, followed by a graduated return to impact activities under the guidance of a Physiotherapist or Remedial Instructor.
refer: Next available appointment with MO.
highlight:
Note:
Beware of referred pain from hip or knee.

genInfo: Cellulitis is inflammation of the skin and subcutaneous tissues due to infection. The most common bacterial infection is Staphlococcus or Streptococcus and it may complicate wounds sustained in dirty conditions such as on exercise or infected blisters. Systemic infection occurs when cellulitis spreads via the blood or lymphatic system and requires treatment with intravenous antibiotics.
history:
Ask about:
• Local heat, redness, pain, swelling.
• Any wound or other break in skin: bite/cut/blister.
• Fever, feeling generally unwell.
• Duration and if it is spreading.
• Tetanus status.
examination:
Check for:
• Swelling, redness and heat in affected area.
• Tenderness on palpation.
• Tracking; red lines radiating upwardsfrom the lesion.
• Yellow crusting lesions; see impetigo.
• Temp, RR, pulse, BP, O2 sats.

For additional images go to - https://dermnetnz.org/topics/cellulitis
management:
Management Basic Level

Document your history and examination findings and refer to a medical officer.
A line may be drawn around the erythematous area to mark the extent of the infection at presentation.

Management Intermediate Level

Treatment: Paracetamol 2 x 500mg tablets qds or Ibuprofen 400mg tablet tds with food. Ensure that the patient is seen by the MO as a matter of priority.
refer: Systemic infection may spread rapidly making the person very ill, refer all cellulitis to MO urgently.
highlight:
Note:

Systemic infection may spread rapidly making the person very ill, refer all cellulitis to MO urgently.

genInfo: A highly contagious bacterial skin infection. It usually occurs around the face and hands, starting as fluid filled blisters, which burst and dry to leave a golden brown crust. The infection is easily spread to other parts of the body or to other persons, unless strict hygiene precautions are taken. It is caused but Staphylococcus aureus or Gp A Streptococcus, which live on the skin of many people.
history:
Ask about:
• Broken skin from cuts or scratches, insect bites, eczema or where a helmet chin strap has rubbed.

• Duration of lesions and their spread.
• Contact with known impetigo sufferer or contact sports.
examination:
Check for:
• Thin walled, fluid filled blisters.
• Yellow, crusted exudate over red/pink areas.
• Temperature. (Do BP/pulse/O2 sats if high)

For additional images go to - https://dermnetnz.org/images/impetigo-images
management:
Management Basic & Intermediate Level

Treatment:
• Antibiotics  (topical or oral) are required so refer to MO.
• Provide appropriate LD chit.

Advice: Patient should be advised not to touch infected area. Bedding, towels, face clothes etc should not be shared and should be washed after use to prevent transmission of infection. If face affected, no shaving until infection has cleared up.
occHealth:
Public Health
Bedding, towels face clothes etc should not be shared and should be washed on a hot cycle (60oC) after use.

Occupational Health
Food handlers should be removed from food handling duty until the condition has cleared. Issue LD B Chit to cover this for max 3/7 and must have MO appointment.
refer: All cases.
highlight:
Immediate referral warning signs

Untreated impetigo may spread and cause the more serious condition of cellulitis. Refer as soon as possible for treatment and review to confirm that the treatment is working.

genInfo: Fungal infections can infect the skin, nails and hair. The 2 most commonly seen are tinea cruris or “jock itch” which tends to flare up in summer and tinea pedis or “athlete’s foot” which is a common condition predisposed to by poor hygiene and occlusive footwear.
history:
Ask about:
• Duration of lesions and their spread.
• Physical and sporting activities
• Footwear (if applicable)
examination:
Trunk or limbs (Tinea Corporis; "Ring Worm"):
Single/multiple plaques with scaling and erythema especially at the edges. Lesions enlarge slowly and clear centrally, hence “ringworm”
https://dermnetnz.org/topics/tinea-corporis

Groin, M>F (Tean Cruris; "Jock itch"):
Associated with athlete’s foot. Involves upper thigh and occasionally the scrotum. Red plaque with scaling especially at the edge. Reddened, moist, glazed skin would indicate a probable candida infection which is a yeast. Treatment is the same as for fungus
https://dermnetnz.org/topics/tinea-cruris

Feet, M>F (Tinea Pedis; "Athlete’s foot"):
Young>Old: Itchy, maceration between toes. Risk factors are swimming, occlusive footwear and hot weather.
Https://dermnetnz.org/topics/tinea-pedis
management:
Management Basic Level

Document your history and examination findings and then refer either to a senior medic or medical officer. Supply appropriate footwear chit.

Management Intermediate Level

Treatment: 
Athlete’s foot: Miconazole nitrate 2% cream and/or mycota powder.

Jock Itch: Clotrimazole 1% cream 

Advice: Air the area by wearing loose-fitting clothes. Take boots/trainers off whenever possible. Wash socks at 60 deg and keep boots clean and dry.
occHealth:
Public Health:
Reinforce personal hygiene message.
refer: Those cases not responding to treatment.

genInfo: Pitted keratolysis is a bacterial-related disorder characterised by pitting on the soles of the feet and,occasionally, the palms of the hand. The appearanceis more dramatic when the feet are wet. There is a variant where there are more diffuse red areas on the soles. It is caused by several bacterial species, including corynebacteria, which proliferate in moist conditions. It tends to affect those who sweat heavily (hyperhidrosis) especially if they wear occlusive footwear for long periods. The pitting is due to destruction of the skin’s top layer by protease enzymes from the bacteria which also produce sulphur causing smelly feet.
history:
Ask about:
• Previous skin problems.
• Sweaty feet.

• Duration of lesions and their spread.
examination:
Check for:
• White skin with punched out pits.
• Sulphur smell.
• Excessive sweating.

For additional images go to -  https://dermnetnz.org/topics/pitted-keratolysis
management:
Management Basic & Intermediate Level

Treatment:
• Wash feet with soap twice daily and dry completely esp. in between toes
.
• Antiseptic soaks with Hibiscrub, Tiseps or Potassium permanganate. Dissolve 1 permitab (400mg) in 4 litres of water.

Advice: Patient should be advised to wear boots for as short a period as possible and wear open-toed sandals whenever possible. 
Reduce foot friction by wearing properly fitted footwear. 
Wear socks which effectively absorb sweat e.g., cotton.
Change if wet.
occHealth:
Public Health
Footwear and towels should not be shared and linen should be washed on a hot cycle (60 celcius) after use.
Keep footwear as dry as practical.
refer: Those cases not responding to hygiene measures as topical antibiotics with or without a prescription strength antiperspirant may be required.
highlight:
Caution:

Potassium permanganate crystals and concentrated solutions are caustic and can burn the skin. Even fairly dilute solutions can irritate skin and repeated use may cause burns. When preparing solutions make sure that the crystals or tablets are fully dissolved in water before using. Potassium permanganate may leave a brown stain on skin and nails as well as the bath or vessel holding the solution.

genInfo: The botfly eggs are deposited on the skin either directly by the female fly or by an intermediate host such as a mosquito or house fly or contact with foliage. The warmth of the skin makes the larva hatch and burrow into the skin producing a painful, boil like swelling. The mature larvae emerge from the skin after 6 weeks and drop into the soil to complete their life cycle. Botflies occur throughout the world in warm damp climates such as Belize, South-East Asia, and sub-Saharan Africa.
history:
History
Ask about:
• Presence of boils.
• Duration of boil, typically lasts for 6 weeks until larva emerges.
• Travel to tropical areas.
examination:
Check for:
Boil and evidence of secondary infection.
investigation: Bubbles of air in olive oil over the boil confirms the presence of a larva.
management:
Management Basic and Intermediate Level

Treatment: The larva has an air hole at the skin surface therefore blocking the breathing tube with white soft paraffin or occlusive tape will deprive it of oxygen and encourage it to wriggle out of its hole. It may then be grasped with forceps and encouraged by gentle pressure on either side of the boil, pressing downwards and inwards to pop out larvae.
Thoroughly irrigate the wound with clean water.
occHealth:
Occupational Health:

Wear long sleeves and use insect repellent.
refer: Refer to MO in all cases.
highlight:
Note:

The larva has a barbed body so forcible extraction can leave body parts behind and lead to secondary infection.

genInfo: A very common tropically acquired skin condition caused by the migration of the Hookworm Larva under the skin. In animals they penetrate the venous system and are transported to the lungs and then intestine but humans are accidental hosts and they are unable to complete their lifecycle and leave a meandering path before dying under the skin.
history:
Ask about:
• Recent travel to tropical location, walking barefoot on the beach or similar activity.
• Intensely itchy lesions.
• Onset can be almost immediate after exposure or delayed for days or weeks.
examination:
Check for:
• Migration of larvae under the skin accompanied by 2-3mm wide red, raised, itchy eruption following their course, extending a few mm per day.
• Most commonly on the feet and in between toes, can also be found on knees, and buttocks.

For additional images go to - https://dermnetnz.org/topics/cutaneous-larva-migrans
management:
Management Basic and Intermediate Level

Treatment:
• Apply calamine lotion or Crotaminton 10% (Eurax) cream for the itch.
• Loratadine 10 mg tablets once daily or Chlorphenamine 4mg qds.
occHealth:
Public Health:
• Prevent by wearing shoes when walking on sand.
• Avoid beaches where dogs foul.
refer: Refer to MO for Mebendazole (Vermox) treatment. Note: Vermox is on the formulary for threadworm treatment but is a prescription only medication (POM) for all other conditions.
highlight:
Note:

Itching of the rash may lead to secondary infection or very occasionally a severe allergic reaction.

genInfo: Cutaneous Leishmaniasis is a parasitic disease of the Tropics and Sub-Tropics and endemic in the Middle East, North Africa and South America. The protozoa parasites are spread by sandflies. The skin infection develops at the site of the sandfly bite and starts as an itchy papule which crusts and forms an ulcer. It may take several weeks to develop and many months to heal with scarring.
history:
Ask about:
• Location.
• Single or multiple lesions.
• Pain or itching.
• Duration of lesion and treatment used.
• Foreign travel in past 6 months
examination:
Check for:
• Deep ulcer with firm edge, not responsive to antibiotic treatment.
• Crusted scab like lesions

For additional images go to  - https://dermnetnz.org/topics/leishmaniasis-images
investigation: Microscopy (if capability exists locally) of aspirated material from edge of ulcer.
management:
Management Basic and Intermediate Level

Advice: The lesion is not contagious but may be covered with a dry dressing to prevent secondary infection. Most lesions heal after months but leave scars.
occHealth:
Public Health:
• Avoid sleeping on jungle floor, wear long sleeves and trousers, peripel clothing and use insect repellant.
• Take particular care to avoid sandfly bites at dusk and dawn.

• Complete Fmed 85.
refer: All patients with suspicious lesions must be seen by MO for referral to a specialist hospital clinic.
highlight:
Note:

Cutaneous leishmaniasis is the most common form of leishmaniasis. Visceral leishmaniasis (kala azar) is a severe form where the parasites infect the vital organs.

genInfo: This is a viral infection caused by the Herpes Simplex virus type 1 (HSV-1). The initial infection usually occurs in childhood and lasts about 2 weeks with fever, malaise and local lymphadenopathy. The virus then resides mainly in the dorsal root ganglion and is reactivated by respiratory infection, hence “cold” sore, sunlight, fatigue or local trauma.
history:
Ask about:
• Tingling sensation around mouth and lips.
• Pain/discomfort.
• Herpetic lesions around mouth.
• Eye symptoms, refer urgently to MO.
• SH: Contact with infected individual.
• PMH: Recent illness or previous episodes in same area.
examination:
Check for:
• Multiple fluid filled vesicles (small blisters).
• Crusts within 24-48hrs.

For additional images go to  - https://dermnetnz.org/topics/herpes-simplex
management:
Management Basic Level

Document your history and examination findings and then refer either to a senior medic or medical officer.

Management Intermediate Level

Treatment:
• Aciclovir 5% cream.
• Paracetamol 2 x 500mg tablets qds or
• Ibuprofen 400mg tablet tds with food.

Advice:
• Topical treatment is only effective if started at onset of symptoms. Advise to present early with any recurrence.
• Infection may be passed on by direct contact.
• Sunscreen may reduce recurrence rate.
occHealth:
Public Health:
• Reinforce personal hygiene message.
• Opportunistic sexual health advice.

Occupational Health:
Sunblock should be used if prone to cold sores or in areas of high sunlight such as operational tours.
refer: Lesions near to eyes must be seen by MO.
highlight:
Immediate referral warning signs:

Refer to MO urgently if any eye symptoms.

genInfo: Shingles is caused by reactivation of the Varicella Zoster, chicken pox, virus often decades after the initial infection. The virus may remain hidden in the nerve cell body of a single nerve, hence appears in the dermatome supplied by that nerve when it is reactivated. Pain may occur up to 5 days before the skin lesion appears followed by a crop of skin blisters. These heal with scarring in 2-3 weeks but the area may remain painful for many months. The thoracic dermatomes are affected in 50% cases .
history:
Ask about:
• Burning pain, numbness, oversensitivity or itching prior to the rash appearing.
• Erythematous rash and grouped vesicles (small blisters).
• Malaise; headache and fever.
• Diabetes.
examination:
Check for:
• Vesicles; initially yellow fluid then blood filled before they crust over.
• Single dermatome affected; belt like rash that does not cross the midline.
• Secondary bacterial infection.
• Eye surface and visual acuity.
• Temp.

For additional images go to  - https://dermnetnz.org/topics/herpes-zoster
management:
Management Basic Level

Document your history and examination findings and then refer to medical officer.

Management Intermediate Level

Advice: Pain can be severe and last months or years.

Refer all cases for effective anti viral treatment.
occHealth:
Public Health:
• The virus may be shed from the blister fluid and contacts with no previous exposure may develop chickenpox.
• Avoid contact with pregnant women and young babies.
refer: Refer all cases for effective anti viral treatment.
highlight:
Immediate referral warning signs:

Any eye or face lesions should be referred to the MO immediately.

genInfo: Warts and verrucae are both caused by the human papilloma virus. They are extremely common and easily transmitted by skin to skin contact with an infected person or for example, a swimming pool changing room floor where somebody with a verruca has trodden. They are often found on the hands but may occur elsewhere on the body. Warts often grow in crops and can disappear spontaneously in a few months but it may take up to 2 years without treatment.
history:
Ask about:
• Duration of symptoms.
• Location.
• Single, multiple.
• Pain or itching.
examination:
Check for:
• Firm, rough, skin coloured, pale or pigmented papules.
• Black pin point dots on the surface when pared.

For additonal images go to - https://dermnetnz.org/topics/viral-warts-images
management:
Management Basic Level

Treatment: Soak in warm water and remove dead skin gently with emery board.

Advice:
• 30-50% disappear spontaneously within 6 months.
• Genital warts: self-referral to Genitourinary Medicine (GUM) clinic.

Management Intermediate Level

Treatment: Salicylic Acid Lactic Acid (Salactol) Wart Paint (not to be used on face or genitals). 
• Soak well, especially plantar warts (verruca), then dry. 
• Gently abrade surface with emery board. 
• Carefully apply a few drops of paint to wart taking care to localise application to affected area. 
• Cover with adhesive plaster, if plantar wart. 
• Leave for 24hrs. 
• Repeat daily, removing old paint.
occHealth:
Public Health:
Spread is by direct contact, sexual contact, bathrooms or swimming baths. Patients with plantar warts (verrucas) should be advised not to walk about in shower, bathroom or swimming pool barefoot.
refer:
Refer:
• Diabetic patients.
• Warts on face, genitalia and peri-anal area.
• Warts under finger or toenails.
highlight:
Note
Pre-teenage girls are now routinely vaccinated to prevent infection with the Human Papilloma Virus strains that have been linked to the development of cervical cancer.

genInfo:
Eczema is a chronic, itchy, scaly inflammation of the skin often associated with a family or personal history of asthma, allergic rhinitis or eczema. “Atopy” is an inherited tendency to allergy present in about 15% of the population. Infantile eczema is relatively common but most children will not have any further symptoms after age 15yrs.
Dry skin is particularly common in the winter months affecting those working outside and in heated buildings. Treatment is the same as for atopic eczema.
history:
Ask about:
• Dry, itchy rash in skin creases and flexor surface (inside) of joints.
• Personal or family history of Atopy.
• Hand dermatitis, exacerbated by irritants.
• Exacerbations may be triggered by psychological stress.
examination:
Check for:
• Inflamed, red skin.
• Itchy, excoriated rash.
• Generalised dry skin with cracking or flaking, particularly over joints.

For additional images go to - https://dermnetnz.org/topics/atopic-dermatitis
management:
Management Basic and Intermediate Level

Treatment: Moisturising creams  (E45 Cream apply three times daily) and bath emoillients (Aqueous Cream).

Advise:
• Avoid soap/detergents or scented cosmetics
• Regular use of emollients to moisturize and as soap substitute. 
• Apply cream in direction of hair growth
• Avoid irritant clothing such as wool/man-made fibres
• Avoid  excessive heat ncluding hot showers/baths.
• Avoid allergens; cats, dogs, house dust mite, where identified.
• Keep fingernails short.
occHealth:
Occupational Health:

Eczema may have significant career implications. It is well recognized that the condition deteriorates in hot, dirty, dusty conditions and secondary infection may be serious. Anyone with more than the very mildest eczema may need to be downgraded and unfit to deploy.
refer:
• Widespread or severe eczema.
• Secondary bacterial infection (yellow crusting or very inflamed skin) or if simple treatment not effective.
highlight:
Immediate referral warning signs

Any signs of a blistering rash on a background of eczema with or without systemic upset (fever/flu like symptoms) requires urgent MO review to exclude eczema herpeticum.

genInfo: Dermatitis is inflammation of the skin which may be due to a number of causes; eczema is a specific type of dermatitis. Contact Dermatitis is chronic, itchy inflammation of the skin caused by an external agent. The cause may be an irritant such as abrasives, chemicals (acids, alkalis), solvents and detergents or an allergen such as plants, fragrances, preservatives or metals such as nickel. Nickel sensitivity is seen in 10% women and 1% men. Individuals with atopic eczema are more susceptible to irritants. Seborrhoeic dermatitis is a common, inflammatory skin condition that causes flaky scales to form on oily areas such as the scalp, eyebrows or inside the ear. It may be due to an overproduction of skin oil and irritation from yeast infection.
history:
Ask about:
• Area of body affected; often hands or localised, e.g. watch strap area.
• History of exposure, which may not always be obvious.
• Rash within hours of exposure or more chronic.
• Dry, itchy rash.
• FH of atopy.
• DH: Medication/Cosmetic use if appropriate.
• SH: Occupation, hobbies.
examination:
Check for: Red, excoriated rash sometimes with blisters.

For additional images go to - https://dermnetnz.org/topics/irritant-contact-dermatitis
management:
Management Basic and Intermediate Level

Treatment: Moisturizing creams and emollients.

Advice:
• Avoid irritants.
• All soap preparations degrease the skin and should be avoided.
• Aqueous cream is a useful soap substitute.
• Emollients should be liberally applied at least twice a day particularly after bathing and more frequently throughout the day if necessary.
occHealth:
Occupational Health:

• Avoid contact with irritants. Wear protective clothing e.g. gloves. Adequate washing and drying facilities should be provided.
• Like eczema, contact dermatitis may have significant career implications. It is essential not to become sensitised in the first place as it may be difficult to treat once established.
refer:
• Widespread rash.
• Secondary bacterial infection.
• If simple treatment not effective.

genInfo:
Naevi or moles are common proliferations of one or more of the normal constituents of the skin. They may be present at birth or develop later, most commonly during childhood or adolescence, peaking in number at puberty. Most are entirely benign, however any concern or suspicion requires referral. 

Malignant melanoma is an increasingly common form of skin cancer due to sun exposure and may have spread by the time it is detected, making treatment difficult.
history:
Ask about:
• New lesion or change in size or colour.
• Itching or pain.
• Irregular border.
• Bleeding, crusting or weeping.
• Age (>30yrs)
• History of melanoma.
• Infection.
• Immunosupression.
• Sun exposure  – especially history of blistering sunburn.
• Other atypical pigmented lesions.
examination:
Check for:
• Visual examination of lesion.
• Document location, size and colour of the lesion and any symptoms as described.

• Consider ABCDE of Melanoma.
  • A-Asymmetry.
  • B-Border (irregular).
  • C-Colour (multiple/various colours or very dark).
  • D-Diameter (>6mm concern).
  • E-Evolution- Changing size, shape, colour.

For additional images go to - https://dermnetnz.org/topics/mole-images
management:
Management Basic & Intermediate Level

Advice: Most do not require any treatment but a routine MO appointment is advised.
occHealth:
Occupational Health:

Advice regarding skin exposure to sun especially on first few days of foreign tours and R&R. Fair skinned/red haired people are particularly at risk.

Use any given opportunity to promote the use of SPF 30+ Mar-Oct to reduce risk of skin cancer
refer:
• Any changing, bleeding, painful lesion
• If patient concerned.
• Family history of melanoma.

genInfo: A collection of fluid in a bubble under the outer layer of the skin, caused by excessive abrasion. The fluid cushions the layers of skin under the blister, protecting them as they heal and provides a natural barrier to infection. Activities such as foot drill, marching or tabbing may be responsible, particularly in hot or humid conditions. Ill-fitting or unconditioned boots increase the likelihood of blister formation.
history:
Ask about:
• Footwear, hygiene and activity level.
examination:
Check for:
• Obvious foot anomalies e.g. scars, bunions, corns or other swellings
• Number, size and location of blisters.
• Note whether the roof of the blister is intact or has ruptured.
• Clear fluid, blood or pus indicating infection.
• Swelling, tenderness or redness of the surrounding skin.

For additional images go to - https://dermnetnz.org/topics/friction-blister
management:
Management Basic Level
Document findings then refer to senior medic or MO.

Management Intermediate Level
Treatment:
• If the blister is small, less than 1cm and painless, leave it alone.
• If the blister is larger but intact and not likely to rupture, it is again best to leave it alone. A blister pad may be applied over it to prevent rupture.
• If the blister is too big or painful, or is likely to rupture, it may be aspirated with a sterile needle and syringe:
• Clean then dry the area.
• Using a sterile needle, puncture the blister at the lower edge and aspirate the fluid until the roof of the blister collapses. Leave this roof in place.
• Apply a non-stick dressing.
• If the blister breaks naturally, clean the area carefully with soap or antiseptic solution. The dead skin can be trimmed away after a few days. Apply a sterile non- stick dressing.
• Specialist dressings such as Compeed, Granuflex, Duoderm or Jelonet / mepitel under a dry dressing may be useful.

Advice:
• During route marches, friction may be reduced by wearing a double layer of socks. Foot powder should be used. Ill- fitting or brand new footwear should be avoided
• Feet should be aired out of boots whenever possible at rest.
• Light duties for runs/lower body PT until starting to heal LD chit B max 3/7.
occHealth:
Occupational Health:

Advice regarding skin exposure to sun especially on first few days of foreign tours and R&R. Fair skinned/red haired people are particularly at risk.
refer: If signs of infection appear, such as pus or swelling, consult the MO.
highlight:
Note:

Tincture of benzoin has traditionally been used by US forces to inject into a blister that has been drained, this is called a “hot shot” It has antiseptic properties but the alcohol mixture is extremely painful on contact with the raw base of the blister and this is not advised.

Cellulitis from infected blisters may spread quickly and requires referral to the MO for treatment with antibiotics.

genInfo: Any injury to the skin where the skin surface is broken may result in secondary infection. In temperate climates minor injuries can be treated simply and generally heal with minimal intervention but in tropical conditions they may be slow to heal or become infected.
history:
Ask about:
• Cause of injury.
• Nature of wound.
• Duration of symptoms.
• Fever/malaise.
• Tetanus status.
• Allergies.
examination:
Check for:
• Temp, pulse, BP.
• Inflammation.
• Erythema  (redness), if significant may indicate Cellulitis.
• Pus or blood stained discharge.
• Lymphadenopathy (swelling of glands)
 in glands near to the injury site.

For additional images go to - https://dermnetnz.org/topics/wound-infections
investigation: If significantly infected, or inflammation not responding to basic treatment then take a swab for culture and sensitivity.
management:
Management Basic Level

Treatment:
• Clean and dress the wound appropriately.
• Review at 24 hours.

Refer: Refer to senior medic, nurse or MO if not improving, unwell or concerns regarding significant infection.


Management Intermediate Level

Treatment: As above.

Refer: Refer to MO for antibiotic therapy if wound not responding to treatment or cellulitis suspected.
occHealth:
Occupational Health
• Refer for Tetanus booster if necessary. Note this is now a combined tetanus, polio and diphtheria vaccination (Revaxis vaccine).
• Food handlers with cuts to the hands should ensure that they are wearing the appropriately coloured dressing for cuts and should not handle food if there is any sign of infection.
refer:
Basic:
Refer: Refer to senior medic, nurse or MO if not improving.

Intermediate:
Refer to MO for antibiotic therapy if wound not responding to treatment or cellulitis suspected.
highlight:
Immediate referral warning signs:

Minor wounds with significant tracking or a febrile patient need to be seen by a MO urgently.

genInfo:
Pain and discomfort as a result of the toenail digging into the surrounding skin.
This is a relatively common problem and can vary from mild discomfort to extremely painful infected and inflamed skin around one or several toes.
history:
Ask about:
• Duration of current symptoms.
• Pain.
• Discharge.
• Previous episodes and treatment.
• Diabetes mellitus.
examination:
Check for:
• Swollen, red, shiny, inflamed skin at edge of nail.
• Pus or bloody discharge.
• Granulation tissue heaped up over nail edge.
• Fungal nail infection.

For additional images go to - https://dermnetnz.org/topics/ingrown-toenail
management:
Management Basic Level

Document your history and examination findings including the extent of inflammation and then refer either to a senior medic or medical officer.

Management Intermediate Level
Treatment:
• Dry dressing.
• Foot soaks.

• Light duties awaiting MO review.
• Ibuprofen or paracetamol analgesia.

Advice:
• Good hygiene.
• No DIY surgery.
• Cut toenails straight across.
• Appropriate footwear that does not press on the inflamed area.
• Allow skin to air where possible.
occHealth:
Occupational Health:

Ingrowing toenails should be dealt with to prevent recurrent problems. They often present when hygiene is difficult such as on exercise and can be incapacitating
refer:
• Nail not responding to the above management within 3 days or one that is severely infected.
• If patient is diabetic.
highlight:
Note:

Diabetics are at risk of serious foot infections and should have regular chiropody review.

genInfo:
Damage to the skin caused by excessive exposure to UV radiation.
The skin becomes red, hot and painful. In extreme cases blistering may occur. The skin may peel a few days after burning.
Severe sunburn, especially in children, may increase risk of skin cancer later in life.
history:
Ask about:
History of prolonged sunbathing or falling asleep in the sun or walking with no shirt on.
Fever/malaise.
Symptoms that could indicate heat injury e.g., occurred on exertion/collapse
examination:
Check for:
• Appearance of a superficial burn with redness of the skin and blistering.
• Painful to touch.

- https://dermnetnz.org/topics/sunburn
management:
Management Basic and Intermediate Level

Treatment:
• A cool bath or shower may help.
• Apply after-sun lotion, moisturiser or calamine lotion.
• If very painful, take Paracetamol 2 x 500mg tablets qds or Ibuprofen 400mg tablet tds with food.
• If the skin is blistered non adherent dressings may be used.
• Review the dressing at 24 hours.

Advice:
• Slip on a hat, Slop on sunblock lotion, Slap on a shirt.
• Keep well hydrated, avoid alcohol.
• Choose sunblock with UVA and UVB coverage
• Keep well hydrated, avoid alcohol.
• Avoid use of ice packs/barriers e.g., petroleum jelly (Vaseline).
occHealth:
Occupational Health
• Sunburn is symptom of neglect and as such a punishable offence.
• Repeated sunburn may predispose to cancerous changes.
refer: Vomiting, fever, headaches or shivering.
highlight:
Note
Those with fair skin and fair or ginger hair are most at risk of sunburn.
Sunblock, a shirt and a hat reduces the risk of burning. It may be best to avoid the sun completely during the hottest part of the day.
Sunblock is issued on deployment and may be held by the QM at other times. Sunblock should be issued for guard duty.

genInfo: Black or white spots on the skin of the face and back due to inflammation of the sweat glands. Acne is chronic inflammation of the sebaceous follicles. Areas typically affected are the face, neck and shoulders. Increased sebum production and the occlusion of the follicle openings in the skin result in the formation of comedones (white and black heads). Microorganisms in the skin then break down the excess sebum into fatty acids which cause inflammation and irritation.
history:
Ask about:
• Distribution; face, shoulders, back and upper chest.
• Age of onset.
• Relation to menstrual cycle.
• Exacerbations may be triggered by stress.
• Previous episodes and treatment.
examination:
Look for:
• Blackheads, whiteheads.
• Pustules or cysts.
• Scarring.

For additional images go to - https://dermnetnz.org/topics/acne
management:
Management Basic Level

Document your history and examination findings and then refer either to a senior medic or medical officer.

Management Intermediate Level 

Mild to moderate:
Treatment: Benzyl Peroxide 5% gel. Apply a thin layer to the whole of the affected area, once or twice daily after washing with soap and water. Warn patient to use white sheets/pillowcases as the gel will bleach the material.

Advice:
• Avoid scratching / picking spots which increases scarring.
• Simple washing with soap and water. Drying vigorously with a rough towel helps to remove oil and to break up black heads.

Moderate to severe:
Refer: Moderate to severe acne should be referred to MO or mild cases not responding to the treatment above.
occHealth:
Occupational Health
• Sunburn is symptom of neglect and as such a punishable offence.
• Repeated sunburn may predispose to cancerous changes.
refer: Moderate to severe acne should be referred to MO or mild cases not responding to the treatment.

genInfo:
Lice are flat, wingless, blood-sucking insects. They lay their eggs (nits) on hair or clothing. There are two main species: the body louse of which the head louse is a variant and the pubic louse. Head lice are common and spread by head to head contact. 
The body louse is mainly seen on homeless people living in unhygienic conditions, spread is by infested clothing or bedding. 
The pubic lice is sexually transmitted and mainly found in young adults. 
Lice induce intense itching, which can result in excoriation and secondary bacterial infection.
history:
Ask about:
• Duration of itching/discomfort.
• Presence of eggs or lice.
• If pubic – signs of other STI e.g., discharge, dysuria
examination:
Check for:
• Nits, or lice in the hair.
• Itchy rash, note site.
• Excoriation due to itching.
• Secondary bacterial infection.

For additional images go to - https://dermnetnz.org/topics/lice
management:
Management Basic Level
Document your history and examination findings and then refer either to a senior medic or medical officer.

Management Intermediate Level
Treatment:
• Malathion for Head lice (Permethrin not recommended according to BNF)
• Permethrin 5%  (only use on skin that is not broken/secondarily infected).
• Chlorphenamine 4mg tablets qds for associated itching.

Advice:
• Head lice. Apply to dry hair and scalp until thoroughly moistened. Leave to dry naturally and after 12 hours shampoo and rinse hair. Comb hair with a nit comb to remove dead lice and eggs. Second application should be used 7 days after first. Supply 2 x 50ml per person
• Pubic lice.Two treatments one week apart are required. Apply to entire skin surface (not head/face) and leave on the skin for 8-12 hrs. Wash off in bath or shower.
• All bedding, clothing and towels must be washed.
occHealth:
Public Health:
• Pubic lice may require referral to GUM clinic to trace and treat sexual contacts.
• All family members, partners should be checked.
• Household contacts should not routinely be treated unless live infestation of pubic lice has been confirmed in other members of the household.

Occupational Health:
Off duties for minimum 24hrs whilst treating. LD chit for 1/7 to enable treatment.
refer: All cases where treatment has failed.

genInfo: An invasion of the epidermis by the scabies mite. Scabies is a highly contagious skin infection and is transmitted during prolonged or frequent skin contact with an infected person. It is not dangerous but causes intense itching which is due to a hypersensitivity reaction and develops 4 -6 weeks after the initial infestation. Classical scabies is not transmitted by towels and sheets etc, although this can occasionally occur. Mites can only survive for a short period away from the human host.
history:
Ask about:
• Itchy rash.
• Burrows, typically between fingers, inside of wrists, ankles and genitalia.
• Excoriaton due to itching and secondary bacterial infection.
examination:
Check for:
• Thorough visual examination of skin, particularly the hands looking for burrows and skin scratching.

For additional images go to - https://dermnetnz.org/images/scabies-images
management:
Management Basic Level

Document your history and examination findings and then refer either to a senior medic or medical officer.

Management Intermediate Level
Treatment:
• Permethrin 5% cream (only use on skin that is not broken/secondarily infected). Two treatments one week apart are required. Apply to entire skin surface (not head/face) and leave on the skin for 8-12 hrs. Wash off in bath or shower.
• Chlorphenamine for associated itching.

Advice:
• Remind patient not to wash their hands after having applied the lotion.
• All bedding, clothing and towels must be washed.
occHealth:
Public Health:
Advise that the whole family, close household contacts and sexual contacts are treated as appropriate.

Occupational Health:
Off duties for minimum 24 hrs whilst treating. LD chit for 1/7 to enable treatment.
refer: If itching persists after one week or is severe.
highlight:
Note:

Itching may continue for weeks even after the mite has been killed.

genInfo: A tick is a small, spider like creature, which feeds on blood by biting the outer skin layer. The creature remains attached to the skin until it fills up with blood and then falls off but this may take several days. Ticks are vectors for a number of diseases such as Lyme disease, Rocky Mountain spotted fever, and Tick Borne Encephalitis, which are injected into the skin on biting.
history: Ask about: Operations, exercises, walks or recreational activities in woodland or areas inhabited by deer or other animals.
examination:
Check for:
• Tick still present.
• Redness, swelling and pain around the bite.
• Rash may be the first sign of Lyme's disease.
management:
Management Basic and Intermediate Level

Treatment: 
 Remove the tick as soon as possible by grasping it close to skin with a pair of forceps, tweezers, or a tick removal tool. Pull gently and firmly perpendicular to the skin. Do not twist the tick. Do not use petroleum jelly, alcohol, nail polish remover, a flame, or other similar methods.
occHealth:
Public Health:
Ticks can transmit Lyme disease.
In some parts of Northern Europe there may be a danger of tick-borne encephalitis.

Occupational Health:
In areas of high risk, take preventative measures such as covering up well, wearing a hat and tucking trousers into socks. Check body at end of day to ensure no ticks in situ as risk of disease increases with time of exposure.
refer:
• Failure to remove part of tick or redness around lesion.
• Flu-like symptoms, headache, muscle aches, neck stiffness, ring-like skin lesion may indicate encephalitis or Lyme disease and must be referred to MO.
highlight:
Note:

The classic early sign of local infection with Lyme disease is a circular, outward expanding rash called erythema chronicum migrans which appears a few days or up to a month after the bite. Early treatment with antibiotics can prevent serious long term cardiovascular and neurological symptoms although arthritis may still occur so refer to MO.

genInfo: Leeches are invertebrates that may live on land or in water and may live on small invertebrates or the blood of larger animals and humans. Only 10% bite, the rest feed off open wounds or decomposing bodies. Blood sucking leeches attach to their host until they become full when they fall off naturally after about 20 minutes. They are found among vegetation of tropical rainforests and breed near springs.
history:
Ask about:
• Site and symptoms.
• Number of leeches.
examination:
Check for: 
Look for leeches still attached or bleeding wounds.
management:
Management Basic & Intermediate Level

Treatment: 
Consider waiting for the leech to fall off naturally in 20-60 minutes. 
Do not pull the leech off which risks leaving the jaws in the skin. 
To remove a leech, use a sharp fingernail or corner of a credit card to break the seal of the oral sucker and remove gently. 
Do not use chemical or burning methods which risk the leech regurgitating its stomach contents. 
Apply pressure to stop bleeding. 
Clean the wound with soap and water and apply antiseptic.
occHealth:
Occupational Health:
• Prevent by wearing boots and thick trousers. Leeches are more easily spotted on light coloured clothing.
• Use of strong insect repellent may help.
refer: Refer to MO if secondarily infected.
highlight:
Note:

Leeches secrete an anti-clotting enzyme into the host’s blood stream which may cause wounds to bleed profusely and there is a risk of secondary infection of the wound.
Allergic or anaphylactic reactions are rare.

genInfo: An acute viral disease caused by the varicella zoster virus that causes blisters of the skin and the mucous membranes. It is a common and generally mild infectious disease characterised by a rash and mild fever. The virus is spread from person to person in airborne droplets. Patients are infectious from about two days before rash appears until about a week later. The Incubation period from being infected to developing the disease is 11 - 21 days.
history:
Ask about:
• History of contact.
• Previous infection / immunisation history.
• Fever.
• Malaise; headache, nausea, sore throat, ear pain.
• Rash.
• Eczema.
• Smoking history.
• Children at home / pregnant contacts.
examination:
Check for:
• Rash on trunk, face and neck
• Clusters of small, red, itchy spots at different stages.
• Fluid filled blisters 2-3mm diameter.
• Temp, pulse and BP.
management:
Management Basic Level

Document your history and examination findings and then refer either to a senior medic or medical officer.

Management Intermediate Level

Treatment:
• Apply calamine lotion or Crotaminton 10% (Eurax) cream for the itch.
• Loratadine 10 mg tablets once daily or Chlorphenamine 4mg qds.
• Avoid ibuprofen – can worsen rash.

Advice:
• Rest, fluids, paracetamol for fever.
• Discourage patient from scratching blisters.
• Avoid contact with pregnant ladies and young babies.
occHealth:
Public Health:

• Admit to MRS or bed down 3/7 at home to minimise the spread of infection. 
• F Med 85; Notifiable Disease Report form. 
• The person is contagious 1 - 5 days before the rash appears and until all the blisters have formed scabs which may take 5 - 10 days.
• There is a vaccination available privately which some young children may have had.
refer:
• Severe cases and all adults.
• Pregnant or less than 4 weeks postnatal.
• Urgent referral if severe headache,
confusion or decreased conscious level, which may indicate encephalitis.
highlight:
Note:

The most common late complication of chicken pox is shingles, caused by reactivation of the varicella zoster virus decades after the initial episode of chickenpox.

Immediate referral warning signs:

Pregnant women and smokers may develop a severe infection and require urgent medical treatment.

genInfo: Dengue fever is caused by the dengue virus, which is endemic throughout the tropics including Belize and Brunei. The Flavivirus is spread by Aedes aegypti mosquito which feed during the day. It is prevalent in urban districts as well as the jungle. It is usually a self resolving illness that needs to be distinguished from Malaria.
history:
Ask about:
• Recent travel to endemic area.
• Sudden onset severe headache, fever, severe muscle and joint pains, hence the name “break-bone fever”.
• High fever up to 41 degrees.
• Malaise, nausea, vomiting, diarrhoea, anorexia.
• Rash with bright red petichiae on legs and chest.
examination:
Check for:
• Temperature, BP, slow pulse.
• Heamorrhagic signs, bruising or bleeding from skin or mucosa.
• “Tourniquet sign” skin bruising from minimal trauma.
investigation:
• The MO may request blood tests to exclude malaria. The FBC shows low platelet count and white cell count.
• The Dengue blot test will confirm diagnosis.
management:
Management Basic and Intermediate Level

Treatment:
• Cool down with tepid sponging and fan.
• Oral fluids to prevent dehydration.
• Paracetamol 2 x 500mg tablets qds.
• Avoid aspirin/ ibuprofen because of bleeding tendency.
occHealth:
Public Health:

•  Fumigation and reservoir elimination of mosquito population.
•  Use of good repellant.
•  Complete FMED 85, Notifiable Disease Report form.
•  Bite avoidance during the day, long sleeves and trousers.
refer: Refer to MO.
highlight:
Note:
• Often misdiagnosed as Malaria or Typhoid fever.
• Potentially can lead to the more serious Dengue Shock Syndrome.
• Avoid aspirin/NSAIDs because of bleeding tendency.

genInfo: Malaria is an acute parasitic disease of the Tropics and Sub-Tropics. Africa is the source of 95% of global infections. The protozoa parasites (Plasmodium) are transmitted by mosquito bites and destroy red blood cells leading to fever and malaise. Some species can cause fatal multi-organ failure. Malaria is the most dangerous parasitic disease of humans (240 million cases and 627,000 deaths per year and rising). Incubation time is from 7-14 days up to 2 months. On travel to an endemic area, risk of the disease can be greatly reduced by prophylactic anti-malarial medication.
history:
Ask about:
• Careful travel history – where, when, how long? Specific areas e.g. city / coast /country / jungle, activities done, prophylactic measures taken, bite.history.

• Fever, following a pattern of spiking every 2-3 days, rigors, shivering.
• Vomiting, diarrhoea and abdominal pain.
• Headache.
• Muscle pain and weakness.
examination:
Check for:
• Temperature, particularly recurrent, cyclical fevers.
• BP, pulse.
• Jaundice.
• Anaemia (pale eyes or lips).
investigation:
• The MO may require blood test.
• Blood is taken at the peak of the fever in FBC bottle and thick and thin blood film.
• Other blood tests for infection may be done.
management:
Management Basic and Intermediate Level

Treatment:
• Cool down with tepid sponging.
• Paracetamol 2 x 500mg tablets qds for fever.
occHealth:
Public Health:

• Bite prevention by wearing long sleeves and trousers particularly at dusk. Use of mosquito nets and DEET insect repellents.Occupational Health 
• Compliance with anti-malarial medication specific to area of travel. 
• Carry malaria warning card.
• Complete FMed 85, Notifiable Disease Report 
form.
refer: Refer to MO urgently for diagnosis and possible hospital admission.
highlight:
Note:

Five species of Plasmodium parasite can infect humans.

Immediate referral warning signs:

Plasmodium falcipaum malaria is a life threatening illness which needs urgent hospital admission.

genInfo:
Scrub typhus is a tick borne Rickettsial bacterial infection causing fever and rash. It is transmitted by the larval stage of the mite which are known as “chiggers” and found in areas of heavy scrub vegetation or sandy riverbanks. 
Severe epidemics of Scrub Typhus occurred in WWII among British troops in Burma and Ceylon and the Americans in Japan.
It is life-threatening
history:
Ask about:
• Recent travel to area of infestation.
• Tick or flea bite.
• Sudden onset of fever, muscle pains, headache.
• Measles like rash, conjunctivitis.
examination:
Check for:
• Temperature, BP, pulse.
• Black necrotic papule (eschar) around the site of the tick bite, may resemble a cigarette burn.
• Measles like rash on trunk.
• Respiratory problems, pneumonia.
• Tender lymphadenopathy.
investigation: The MO may request the Weil-Felix blood test which is available but unreliable.
management:
Management Basic and Intermediate Level

Treatment:
• Cool down with tepid sponging and fan.
• Paracetamol 2 x 500mg tablets qds.

• AVOID aspirin or ibuprofen.
occHealth:
Public Health:
Bite avoidance; thick trousers and boots when walking through vegetation.

Use of nets and DEET insect repellents.

Treatment of clothing/field kit with permethrin
refer: Refer to MO.
highlight:
Note:

Without antibiotic treatment it may cause a fatal infection, but it responds well to Doxycycline, Chloramphenicol or Azithromycin. Antibiotic resistance is developing and individuals with HIV may be particularly susceptible.

genInfo: Dog bites are more common than cat bites and these two species account for the majority of (non-human) animal bite wounds. Dog bites typically cause a crushing-type wound because of their rounded teeth and strong jaws. Such extreme pressure may damage deeper structures such as bones, vessels, tendons, muscle, and nerves. The sharp pointed teeth of cats usually cause puncture wounds and lacerations which may rapidly become infected. Human bites may be intentional or accidental when somebody is punched in the face during a fight.
history:
Ask about:
• Location and number of bites.
• Time of bite.
• Pain and blood loss.
• Type of animal and health, ie vaccinated pet dog or unwell stray.
• Location of animal now (to follow up any possibility of rabies infection).
• Circumstances surrounding the bite ie, provoked or defensive bite versus unprovoked bite.
• PMH: Diabetes, immunocompromise.
• Vaccination history; tetanus and rabies.
examination:
Check for:
• Temp, Pulse and BP, tearing wounds may cause severe bleeding.
• Tendon injury, particularly in hand injury.
• Bone injury, particularly of the skull.
• Abdominal wounds may indicate damage to underlying structures.
• Foreign bodies such as teeth in the wound.
management:
Management Basic Level

Treatment: Irrigate profusely with soap and water or antiseptic solution.

Management Intermediate Level
Treatment:
• Continue to irrigate profusely with soap and water or antiseptic solution.
• Bandage/pressure dressing to stop the bleeding.
• Splint the area if it is an extremity like a finger or hand.
• Paracetamol 2 x 500mg tablets qds.
refer: Refer to MO urgently.
highlight:
Note:

All animal / human bites must be seen by the MO as there is a high risk of infection. For this reason they are generally not sutured and steristrips should be applied with caution as they may promote deep infection.

Immediate referral warning signs:

Damage to deep structures or profuse bleeding must be seen by the MO immediately. Possible rabies infection must be treated as a medical emergency as it is generally fatal.

genInfo: Stings by wasps or bees can be painful but usually only cause a localised inflammatory reaction. Some individuals may be allergic to stings and have a stronger localised reaction or a life threatening anaphylactic reaction.
history:
Ask about:
• Site and time of sting.
• Pain.
• Light headedness, difficulty breathing.
• Known allergy to wasp sting.
examination:
Check for:
• Localised weal and oedema.
• Surrounding flare.
• Pallor.
• Pulse and BP .
management:
Management Basic Level

Treatment:
• Remove sting if still in skin.
• Cold compress; ice held against the site for a few minutes.
• Crotamiton 10% (Eurax) cream.

Refer: Refer to MO or senior medic if any signs or symptoms of acute anaphylaxis.

Management Intermediate Level

Treatment: 
If Crotaminton 10% (Eurax) cream is not effective then: Loratadine 10mg tablets or Chlorphenamine 4mg tablets qds.

Refer: As above and if signs of infection.
occHealth:
Occupational Health:

Chlorphenamine causes drowsiness, so caution in continuing certain work or driving. 

Anyone with a history of allergic reaction to stings must be seen by the MO to discuss grading.
refer: Refer to MO or senior medic if any signs or symptoms of acute anaphylaxis.
highlight:
Immediate referral warning signs:

See Anaphylaxis Guidelines

Don't forget Oxygen!

Adrenaline: 1ml 1:1000 solution in prefilled syringe

genInfo:
Snakes are either venomous or non venomous who kill their prey by constriction. Non venomous snakes may still bite causing deep puncture wounds which may become infected. Venomous snakes can control whether they inject their venom or give a “dry bite”. Envenomation may cause local effects at the site of the bite and systemic effects or anaphylaxis which may be life threatening and need urgent medical care. The outcome of snake bites depends on the species of snake, the area of the body bitten, the amount of venom injected and the health of the victim.
Snake bites in the UK are rarely serious but all should be treated as an emergency. Worldwide, approx. 250 species of snake are considered dangerous, usually in tropical areas
history:
Ask about:
• Type of snake, colour, size, pattern.
• Time since bite.
• Location of bite.
• Lethargy, weakness, nausea, and vomiting.
• PMH
examination:
Check for:
• BP, pulse. Respiratory rate, O2 sats.
• Pain, swelling, redness, blistering at site of bite.
• Signs of neurotoxicity: numbness, muscle weakness and breathing difficulty.
• Coagulopathy: bruising and bleeding.
management:
Management Basic and Intermediate Level

Treatment:
• Arrange urgent evacuation. Do not risk further bites or delay evacuation catching the snake.
• Keep the victim calm, lie flat. Panic increases blood flow and spread of venom.
• Allow bite to bleed freely, clean, apply Betadine soak.
• Apply direct pressure over bite site using a pressure bandage proximal to the bite site to delay venom absorption. Do not cut or use a tourniquet.
• Immobilise affected limb but do not elevate so as to minimise blood returning to the heart and vital organs.
• Remove boots, watch, rings and constrictive clothing.
• Do not give any food, drink or medication. 
• Identify snake where possible.
occHealth:
Occupational Health:

Wear stout boots and tread carefully.
refer:
Refer to MO urgently.

Have IV access equipment, oxygen, atropine and morphine available for MO.
highlight:
Note:

Elapids and viper envenomation may cause coagulopathy; spontaneous bleeding from the mouth, nose and internal organs including the brain and intestines. The victim may die of blood loss. Venom from elapids, including cobras, kraits, mambas, sea snakes causes neurotoxicity. Symptoms include visual disturbances, paresthesia, difficulty speaking and breathing and may lead to fatal respiratory failure. Most venom causes necrosis of muscle tissue which can clog the kidneys causing fatal renal failure. Spitting cobras can spit venom in their victims' eyes causing pain and sometimes blindness.

genInfo: Scorpion stings are a major public health problem in many tropical countries. For every person killed by a poisonous snake, 10 are killed by a poisonous scorpion. In Mexico, 1000 deaths from scorpion stings occur per year. Scorpions can be found outside their normal range of distribution when they accidentally crawl into luggage, boxes, containers, or shoes and are unwittingly transported home via human travellers. Out of 1500 scorpion species, only 50 are dangerous to humans and in general, scorpions are not aggressive. They are nocturnal creatures hunting during the night and hiding in crevices and burrows during the day to avoid the light. Scorpions are shy creatures and only sting if threatened, cornered, or disturbed by being sat or stepped upon. Accidental human stinging occurs when hands and feet are put in their hiding places.
history:
Ask about:
• Site and time of sting.
• Abdominal pain, nausea and vomiting.
• Painful, local reaction around the site of the sting – pain can be severe.
examination:
Check for:
• Localised weal and oedema.
• Fast or slow pulse and pallor, cardiovascular failure.
• Fast respiratory rate, respiratory failure.
• Sweating, increased tears and saliva production.
• Check temp, pulse and BP which may be high or low.
• O2 sats if available.
management:
Management Basic and Intermediate Level

Treatment: 
• Support Airway, Breathing and Circulation.
