• Keep the victim calm, lie flat; panic increases blood flow and spread of venom.
• Remove boots, watch, rings and constrictive clothing.
• Cleanse site thoroughly; apply Betadine soaked gauze.
• Immobilise affected limb below level of heart to delay absorption.
• Have IV access equipment, oxygen, atropine and morphine available for MO.
• Ice packs may slow early absorption of the venom.
occHealth:
Occupational Health:

Check clothing and boots before putting them on.
refer:
Refer to MO immediately for evacuation to hospital.

Have IV access equipment, oxygen, atropine and morphine available for MO.
highlight:
Note:

Some species have life-threatening sting but do not always use fatal dose of venom. Systemic envenomation is more common in children and may occur within minutes. Antivenom is available for some species.

genInfo: Jellyfish are found in every ocean and a few species exist in fresh water. They are generally found near the surface or washed up on the beach. Their tentacles contain thousands of tiny stingers which inject venom on contact. Stings are generally accidental and should be suspected if there is sudden pain and the development of painful rash when swimming. Many types are harmless but he box jellyfish venom is the most deadly venom in the entire animal world.. (found in warm Pacific / Indian ocean).
history:
Ask about:
• Colour and shape of Jellyfish.
• Time and site of sting.

• Intense, stinging pain at site of sting.
• Presence of rash or swelling at site.

• Breathing difficulty or chest pain.
• Nausea, vomiting and abdominal pain.
• Symptoms of a mild sting tend to improve in a few hours.
examination:
Check for:
• Pulse, BP, signs of shock.
• Lines of contact red streaks dotted with wheals with surrounding flare
• Respiratory difficulty or full blown anaphylaxis.
• Irregular pulse, blood pressure changes, cardiac arrest.
• Decreased conscious level.
management:
Management Basic and Intermediate Level

Treatment:
• People stung by jellyfish should be removed from the sea to prevent drowning.
• Tentacles should be washed off with seawater or lifted off carefully wearing gloves or using tweezers. Fresh water, alcoholic solutions, ammonia and urine should be avoided as they may cause the release of additional venom. Vinegar is only used for box jelly fish stings, not Portuguese Man o’ War stings where it can cause further discharge of stinging nematocysts.
• Ice packs/sea water or a slurry of baking soda (sodium bicarbonate) can be useful for treating UK species. Hot baths may help and a safety razor or credit card edge can be used to shave away any remaining nematocysts.
occHealth:
Occupational Health:

Protective clothing such as wet suits or lycra swim suits should be worn in areas of risk.
refer:
Refer to MO for analgesia 

Evacuate immediately and be prepared to deal with anaphylaxis
highlight:
Note:

• Box Jellyfish stings may be rapidly life threatening. Multiple stings are excruciatingly painful and can cause anaphylaxis, collapse, respiratory arrest and death. Box jellyfish occur mainly in Indo-Pacific region.
• Portuguese Man o’ War may cause heart failure.
• Even beached or dying jelly fish may still sting

genInfo: Stingrays are not aggressive creatures and most stings are accidental when the flat creature is stepped upon in shallow water. Injury is by laceration or puncture wounds from the serrated spines at the end of the tail. They also have a stinger apparatus which contains venom but is not always released.
history:
Ask about:
• Time and site of sting – barb may remain at site
• Intense pain.
• Nausea, vomiting, muscle cramps or chills.
examination:
Check for:
• Swelling and redness at site of wound.
• Low blood pressure.
• Irregular, rapid heartbeat.
• Difficulty breathing or anaphylaxis.
• Convulsions.
management:
Management Basic Level

Document your history and examination findings and refer to a medical officer.

Management Intermediate Level

Treatment:
• Remove spine from wound if superficial (see note below).
• Hot water kills stingray venom and may relieve associated pain. Soak area in water ideally 43-46 degrees, taking care not to burn patient or cause further discomfort. Reheat/change water every 10 mins and soak for 30-90 mins.
• Remove rings or constrictive clothing.
occHealth:
Occupational Health:

Protective clothing such as wet suits or lycra swim suits should be worn in areas of risk.
refer: Refer to MO and prepare casevac.
highlight:
Note:

Stingray stings are rarely fatal unless the chest or abdomen is pierced when death may occur from blood loss. In these cases, the barb should be left in place until medical help is reached.

genInfo: The Sad Soldier is a frequent presentation and may be due to depression. Depression is one of the most common mood disorders that can affect anyone at any time. Depression is a serious condition characterised by persistent and intense feelings of sadness for extended periods. Depression can impact on everyday activities and effect performance. Occasionally, they may also feel as if life isn’t worth living.
history:
Ask about:
• Active attempts to self-harm (refer to 15.2 Self-harm)
• Persistent low mood 
• Loss of enjoyment
• Reduced energy and motivation
• Difficulty concentrating
• Feelings of worthlessness, guilt or hopelessness.
• Changes in appetite or sleep
• Loss of libido (low sex drive)
• Recurrent thoughts of death or suicide.
• Trigger Events (i.e., significant precursory events leading to onset of symptoms)
• Alcohol intake and excess use
examination:
Mental State Examination
Quiet, poor eye contact, reduced facial expression, appears slow in movement and response to questions. May be unsettled and anxious. Preoccupied with negative thinking.
investigation:
Complete GAD-7 and PHQ-9 (questionnaires - either use Primary Medical Record system or online versions)

https://www.mdcalc.com/calc/1727/gad7-general-anxiety-disorder7

https://www.mdcalc.com/calc/1725/phq9-patient-health-questionnaire9
management:
Management Basic Level
• Review in a quiet confidential space (if practical)
• Introduce yourself
• Be approachable and courteous.
• Be non-judgmental.
• Be comfortable with silence
• Use both open and closed questioning. Logical, curious questions.
• Empathise, Reflect, Validate

Management Intermediate Level
• Careful documentation of signs and symptoms
• Signpost to relevant support services
refer: All cases must be discussed with an SNO/MO
highlight:
Note

Immediate referral warning signs – All episodes of self-harm must be escalated to the MO or FMHT (if available)

genInfo:
Self-harm is common but can be difficult to talk about and hard for others to understand. Causing harm to oneself can manifest in various direct or indirect behaviours such as self-cutting, burning, or poisoning, having unsafe sex or misusing drugs and alcohol. 

When someone self-harms, they are usually feeling very emotional and/or distressed and they often use self-harm as a coping strategy to alleviate these feelings. 

Self-harm can be a strong predictor of future suicide risk.
history:
Ask about:
• Injury (consider emergency or urgent action).
• Mechanism of injury.
• Trigger events (i.e., significant precursory events leading to onset of self-harm).
• Drug and/or alcohol use.
• Thoughts and/or intent of further self harm. 
• Thoughts and/or intent of death or suicide.
• Current support networks.
examination:
Check for:
• Obvious signs of injury.
• Signs of hidden injury (i.e., keeping fully covered up, even in hot weather).
• Signs of distress. 
• Expressing feelings of low mood
• Thoughts of despair and/or hopelessness 
• Changes noted in usual habits or behaviour
investigation:
Investigation 
• Review in a quiet and private space (where practicable).
• Introduce yourself.
• Consider confidentiality.
• Don’t panic.
• Be non-judgmental.
• Use both open and closed questioning.
• Be curious.
• Actively listen.
• Be comfortable with silence.
management:
Management Basic and Intermediate Level

• Careful documentation of history and examination findings and then refer all episodes of self-harm to the MO and/or FMHT (if available).
• Consider emergency or urgent action in relation to any injuries and/or active self-harm behaviours. 
• Refer to 11.15 for Infected Wound/Minor Skin Injury.
• Refer to 15.1 for Sad Soldier.
• Signpost to relevant support services.
occHealth:
Occupational Health
Consider individuals’ roles, responsibilities, and potential associated risks of self-harm (i.e., access to weapons).
refer: All episodes of self-harm must be escalated to the MO and/or FMHT (if available).
highlight:
Immediate referral warning signs

All episodes of self-harm should be taken seriously and must be escalated to the MO and/or FMHT (if available).

genInfo:
Emergency Medically Unwell Protocol

The ABCDE Approach
Unlike <C>ABCDE, which is tailored towards managing the trauma patient, the ABCDE approach is for assessing medically unwell patients. The main difference is small C, which aims to look for signs of dehydration instead of blood loss.
history: This protocol assumes the patient is too unwell to give a history at this point
examination:
ABCDE --> See Management

Attach monitoring
management:
A: Airway --> Can the patient talk?
    - Yes? Move to B
    - No?
       - Check for airway obstruction
          - snoring, stridor, FB, secretions, vomit, blood
       - Perform airway manoeuvres
          - head tilt/ chin lift, jaw thrust
       - If reduced GCS, consider airway adjuncts
          - OPA, NPA, LMA, iGel
B: Breathing
    - Observations --> RR, sats
    - RISE NtwelveFALL
    - O2 if sats < 94%
C: Circulation
    - Observations --> HR, BP
    - Fluid assessment -  check for signs of dehydration
      - cool hands, reduced skin turgor over the clavicle
      - CRT > 2 seconds
      - Dry lips and mouth
      - Weak rapid pulse, reduced urine output
    - Clinically dehydrated? --> Discuss with MO
D: Disability
    - Observations --> Blood glucose
    - AVPU/GCS
    - PEARL
E: Exposure
    - Observations --> Temperature
    - Abdominal exam
    - Check calves --> pain, redness, swelling, warmth
    - Check for rashes/ bleeding/ bruising

*Reduced Skin Turgor 
Pinch the skin overlying the clavicle.
Let go – if the skin remains in the ‘pinched’ position, 
this is known as reduced skin turgor. It is a sign of dehydration.
refer: Have all patients assessed by MO
highlight:
A: Airway --> Can the patient talk?
B: Breathing
C: Circulation
D: Disability
E: Exposure

genInfo:
Sudden patient deterioration!

Could this be anaphylaxis?
history:
Causes:
Food: Nuts, legumes,shellfish egg, milk
Drugs: Antibiotics, NSAIDs, opiates
Idiopathic: No clear cause
examination:
ABCDE Assessment

Attach monitoring

Does the patient have:
A – Stridor, hoarse voice, throat closure?
B – Difficulty in breathing, wheeze, tight chest, cyanosis, Sats<92%?
C – Signs ofshock, dizziness, collapse, pale, clammy, reduced GCS,systolic BP <90?
management:
Remove cause (if possible)

|-->  IMMEDIATELY give 0.5ml IM 1:1000 Adrenaline or 
| EpiPen (EpiPen is usually 0.3 mg so 2 * may be needed.)
|
|  Administer 15L/min Oxygen via non rebreathe mask
|
|   No improvement after 3-5 minutes --> Repeat up to three doses

Attach monitoring , Gain IV access

Give 250 ml boluses of IV 0.9% NaCl
Aim for systolic BP >90mmHg or for a palpable radial pulse

Administer 5mg Salbutamol via nebuliser
OR 10 puffs Salbutamol inhaler via spacer

Give 4mg Chlorphenamine orally if able to swallow

Evacuate to hospital
refer: Alert MO as soon as problem detected
highlight:
Alert MO as soon as problem detected

Begin immediate evacuation to hospital while treatment ongoing

Low sats detected during any encounter <94 %
history:
ABCDE Assessment first
Take a history --> See Management
examination:
Patients Sats < 94%

Attach monitoring
management:

+
Alert MO: Begin immediate evacuation to hospital

ABCDE Assessment 
Take a history

RR<8? --> Consider cause of reduced resp rate: 
   |                head injury, opioid overdose, low GCS
   |
   ---> Support airway --> Give supplemental breaths 
           using BVM
           Aim for RR of 10-14rpm

Asymmetrical chest movement? 
Reduced air entry on one side? 
Consider spontaneous pneumothorax --> Discuss with MO

Wheeze? -> Consider allergy / asthma -> Asthma protocol

Crackles heard on chest exam?  Infective symptoms?
(e.g. runny nose, productive cough, high temperature)
    ---> Consider chest infection --> THINK SEPSIS

Persistent hypotension with hypoxia? Clear chest on examination? No infective symptoms?
   ---> Consider blood clot on lung --> Discuss with MO

Continue to reassess using ABCDE

Evacuate to hospita

genInfo:
What is Sepsis?

Sepsis is an overwhelming inflammatory response to an infection. It is a life threatening medical emergency. 

Timely recognition and treatment is essential.
history:
Could this be sepsis?

❑ High heartrate or weak pulse?

❑ Shortness of breath?

❑ Fever,shivering, or feeling very cold?

❑ Extreme pain or discomfort?

❑ Confusion or disorientation?

❑ Clammy or sweaty skin?
examination:
Sepsis Screening Tool

Two of the following:
❑ Respiratory rate ≥22
❑ GCS < 15
❑ Systolic BP ≤100

Two or more present? --> Alert MO

Commence treatment
+
Evacuate to hospital
management:
Sepsis Treatment

ABCDE

Attach monitoring

Oxygen --> Aim sats >94%

IV Access --> 500ml 0.9% NaCl IV STAT

IV Antibiotics:
  1.2g Co-Amoxiclav given over 3-4min 
  OR
  2g Ceftriaxone given over 5 min

Monitor urine output

Evacuate to hospital
refer: Alert MO as soon as problem detected
highlight:
Alert MO as soon as problem detected

Begin immediate evacuation to hospital while treatment ongoing

condition: Seizures in response to acute event
genInfo: Emergency Seizure Protocol
history:
Status Epilepticus

A seizure lasting > 5min
OR 
Multiple seizures over a short period without recovery 

This is a Medical Emergency.
examination: Temperature
management:
➢ Start timing seizure
➢ Protect head and limbs from injury
➢ Remove sharp objects from pockets
➢ Loosen clothing around the neck

[DO NOT RESTRAIN PATIENT OR PUT ANYTHING IN THEIR MOUTH]

Administer 15L/min OXYGEN via non rebreathe mask

Alert MO --> Begin immediate evacuation to hospital

Check blood glucose -> BG <4mmol/l? -> HYPOGLYAEMIA protocol

Check temperature ->38 deg cel -> Commence cooling
                                                             Strip, Soak, Fan

Seizures last > 5 min?
 - Administer 10-20mg Rectal Diazepam 
   OR 10mg Buccal Midazolam
 - Repeat after 10min if still seizing 
 - Maximum 2 doses
 - Evacuate to Hospital
 - Continue Oxygen --> Monitor continously
 - DO NOT delay evacuation for further treatment

Seizures last < 5 min?
 - ABCDE assessment
 - Support Airway --> Recovery pos, consider NPA
 - Gain IV access
 - Record detail of seizure -> Time, AVPU, description
refer: Alert MO --> Begin immediate evacuation to hospital
highlight:
Alert MO --> Begin immediate evacuation to hospital

See management

genInfo: Emergency Hypoglycaemia Protocol
history:
Does the patient have:

❑ Hunger?
❑ Shaking?
❑ Sweating?
❑ Blurred vision?
❑ Dizziness?
❑ Headache?
❑ Irritability?
❑ Weakness?
❑ Confusion?
❑ Drowsiness?
❑ Seizure?
examination: ABCDE
investigation:
Blood glucose --> BG <4mmol/l ? --> Confirmed hypoglycaemia 

Alert MO
management:
Confirmed hypoglycaemia?

Alert MO

Patient uncooperative, unable to swallow or unconscious?

 - Begin immediate evacuation to hospital
 - ABCDE Assessment
 - Gain IV access
 - Administer 200ml of 10% glucose IV
   OR
   Administer glucagon 1mg IM
 - Recheck BG after 10-15min
 - BG < 4 mmol/l --> Repeat glucose up to 3 times
   --> if still < 4 then evacuate to hospital
 - BG > 4 mmol/l then follow same advice below*.

Patient co-operative and able to swallow?
 - Give 15-20g of fast acting carbohydrate
   e.g. sweets, cake, sugary drink
   OR
   1-2 tubes 40% glucose oral gel

 - Recheck BG after 10-15min
 - BG < 4 mmol/l --> Repeat above up to 3 times
    --> If still < 4 follow uncooperative algorithm above
 - *BG > 4 mmol/l 
     --> Give long active carb e.g. bread, buscuits
           (If received glucagon, give larger carb portion)
     --> Refer to MO

genInfo: Emergency Hypothermia Protocol
history:
Does the patient have:
❑ Mood changes? 
❑ Cold skin?
❑ Confusion? 
❑ Shivering (or absence of)?
❑ Speech disturbances? 
❑ Reduced consciousness?

YES? --> Possible hypothermia --> Go to Management
examination:
ABCDE Assessment

Temperature
management:
➢ Move into warm shelter where able
➢ Lie patient on insulated surface
➢ Remove wet clothes and dry the skin
➢ Apply monitoring
[Handle patient gently to reduce the risk of cardiac arrhythmias]

ABCDE Assessment

Temp < 30 deg celsius - Severe
Temp 30-32 deg celsius - Moderate
 - ALERT MO
 - Commence passive rewarming (see below*)
 - Gain IV access
 - Correct hypoglycaemia (if present = BG < 4 mmol/l)
 - DO NOT allow patient to walk -> Gently evacuate by stretcher to MO

Temp 32-35 deg celsius - Mild
 - Commence passive rewarming (see below*)
 - Evacuate when warm

* Passive Rewarming
• Wrap in warm blankets -->  incl. back and sides of head
•  Place chemical handwarmers in armpits, groin and beside neck [DO NOT place on bare skin]
•  If conscious --> give a warm sweet drink
refer: Temp: <32 then Alert MO
highlight: Temp: <32 then Alert MO

 --> Administer 15L/min O2 via non rebreathe mask

Airway  burn or compromise?

YES? 
  --> Perform surgical cricothyroidotomy
  --> Burns First Aid (see below*)
  --> Alert MO
  --> Evacuate to Hospital


No?
 - Systolic BP < 90?
   - YES?
      --> Gain IV Access
      --> Give 500ml 0.9% NaCl IV bolus. 
            Aim systolic BP >90, max 4 boluses
   - No?
     --> Commence Burns First Aid (see below*)
  - Alert MO
  - Evacuate to Hospital

*Burns First Aid:
The 4 C’s
COOL --> with cool (not cold), clean water for 20-30mins
CLEAN --> with damp dressings. Remove debris. Do not use oils or gels
COVER --> with loose strips of clingfilm or burns bag. Avoid wrapping around burn.
COMFORT --> Administer pain relief. Give oral fluids. Keep casualty warm
refer: Alert MO
highlight:
Alert MO --> Begin immediate evacuation to hospital
